title: Works with Lookout Tower
text:
I felt like I needed a Paw Patrol car lesson while shopping for cars to fit in the Lookout Tower. Let me tell you there are three main lines I found on Amazon, Spin Masters website, and in Target/Walmart:
- Basic Vehicles
- Transforming Vehicles
- Ultimate Rescue Vehicles

I wanted cars that would fit the Lookout Tower, and finally figured out that although some people may say that the Ultimate Rescue line fits in the tower, they are the biggest of the three lines and some reviews say those are too big.

The Basic Vehicles are the original vehicles (the Basic Chase car comes with the Lookout Tower) and those were originally intended to be the cars for the tower. The Basic Rubble car is simply called “Rubbles Diggin Bulldozer”. However, the Basic line is hardest to find, and they are currently either marked up by third party sellers on Amazon or I could only find one or two Basic cars at each Target I visited.

Enter this Transforming line. They are a bit smaller than the Ultimate Rescue, and I was able to find them for $12.99 each on Amazon. They all have a little button that pops out the pups gear. My kids like popping out Rubble's tools and for the most part can reset them themselves (ages 2.5 and 4).

Long story short, this will work in the Lookout Tower. Best of luck finding them all for your kid.

- Basic Vehicles
- Transforming Vehicles

I wanted cars that would fit the Lookout Tower, and finally figured out that although some people may say that the Ultimate Rescue line fits in the tower, they are the biggest of the three lines and some reviews say those are too big.

The Basic Zuma car is simply called “Zumas Hovercraft”. However, the Basic line is hardest to find, and they are currently either marked up by third party sellers on Amazon or I could only find one or two Basic cars at each Target I visited.

Enter this Transforming line. They are a bit smaller than the Ultimate Rescue, and I was able to find them for $12.99 each on Amazon. They all have a little button that pops out the pups gear. For Zuma, it's actuslly a little frustrating that my 2.5 year old can't reset the gear by himself because you have to push it in gently at the right angle while gently closing the hood, but all of the other pups seem fine for him to do himself.

Long story short, this will work in the Lookout Tower. Best of luck finding them all for your kid.

title: Prefer Color Wonder coloring books over this Stow n Go
text:
My 2 and 4 year old have been Color Wonder Mess Free fans for the past couple years. They love the Frozen designs and we have had no problems with markers drying out and absolutely zero mess. They of course love this, but I personally will continue to buy the coloring book plus 5 markers that come in a bag for typically $7-$8 dollars. This stow and go case is sturdy and decent quality (and would be convenient for an airplane or road trip!), but I think this product is pretty consumable and my kids will fly through the 24 coloring pages in a couple sittings, so there isn't much need for long term storage. There are included stickers that are meant to decorate the case, which is fun for my kids, but this is not a very attractive gift option in the plain blue case with no exterior packaging.
Overall we love Color Wonder and they are fun designs for anyone who loves Frozen. Personally I would prefer to pay half the price and get the Color Wonder Frozen set with 18 pages and 5 markers without a case and stickers.

title: Easy enough for a 3 year old to handle
text: My 3 year old can squeeze these by herself and get the caps on and off. Other brands are too difficult for her to use by herself.

title: The wood parts are great, but the plastic parts are lacking
text: My 2.5 year old enjoys this toy, but it is not something he can play with by himself. My 4 year old cannot play with it by herself either, and I even was occasionally having problems getting the wheels off, switching the cab back and forth between the dump truck and carrier, and extending the carrier's ramp up and down without feeling like I was going to break any of the plastic pieces. The carrier ramp is constantly falling off and the tops of the little cars don't stay securely attached either. If you tilt a little car at all, the plastic top will fall right off. (We haven't experienced the top falling off or the wheels being difficult to change on the full size Automoblox cars we have, just these minis.)  Overall my kids still enjoy this, and if I play with them the whole time, I can help switch things back and forth. But they cannot play independently with them and I wish it was designed differently because the concept is good.

title: Not ideal for 2 kids to share
text: I always appreciate solid wooden toys, and these cars are made with nice wood and are very sturdy. I'm sure they will last a very long time and hold up well. The concept is very simple but classic. There are two car fronts, two car backs, two sets of four wheels.... BUT, only one middle. This is where the toy falls short of perfect and creates problems when my 2 and 3 year old are both playing. The middle is the part with the holes that the rounded top of the car snaps in to. Our set came with a police top and a race car top, but only one can be used at a time since there is only one middle. Therefore one kid is left with only a front and back of a car with no middle or top. It seems like it would have been so easy to include a second middle, and that would have made a 5 star product. You can interchange all of the pieces and mix and match cars, but in the end you are limited to only having one full car.

title: Fun craft for 5+
text: This is a cute little craft for kids! The end result is not overly impressive since it's just felt, but it's still cute and a good craft to take 30 min or so.

title: Another M&D hit
text: Our play kitchen is well stocked with Melissa and Doug play food because they seem to have the brightest colors, best sets, and high quality. My 2 and 3 year old love everything from them, and this is no exception. My kids love filling the blender and making pretend smoothies!

title: Amusing toy
text: This toy is kinda hilarious with the randomness of a semi, dinosaurs and stamps. The quality is not very great, but not the worst either. I would feel much better about paying $10 for it, but if we are measuring the value based on how much my 2 year old likes it, then $20 is reasonable. It's also amusing to read the poorly worded English on the box, but it is definitely clear that the seller wants you to be happy and they will refund or replace your toy within 12 months if it breaks for any reason. One thing to note is the cab on the semi doesn't turn by itself, it is all one piece that you have to push around and turn at the same time. It would have been better if it moved more realistically.

title: Surprising fun for 2 and 3 year old; perfect stocking stuffers
text: I thought my kids may be a bit too young at 2 and 3 to appreciate this, but they played with it for over an hour the first time they each opened an egg. I'm sure it won't stay that interesting for too long, but I plan to only pull this out every couple months or so so they have renewed interest each time. They are the perfect size for stocking stuffers too!!

title: A more advanced play doh set
text: We just got the Play Doh kitchen creations ice cream set and this bakery creations set for our 2 and almost 4 year old. The ice cream set is more suited for sharing and for younger kids and is better for their ages now. This bakery creation set, while awesome, is more intricate with all of the molds and suggested creations (whereas the ice cream one the kids basically just make scoops and popsicles). This set has some pretty elaborate suggestions for what to make, such as layered cakes with piping, filled tarts and macaroons. It really is pretty cool, but probably best for older kids!!

title: Perfect for 2 kids to share
text: This set is super fun for my 3 year old! It comes with 6 mini play doh colors (3 are sparkly confetti colors), 2 ice cream dishes, 2 regular cones, 2 waffle cones, 2 banana split bowls, banana, 2 spoons, a fun frosting/whipped cream tool, popsicle sticks, and a couple other small accessories. It really is perfect for my 2 and 3 year old to share this set because it comes with 2 of almost everything. That's a win for our family!

title: Perfect for Thomas lovers
text:
My 2 year old loves his wooden train tracks and Thomas trains!! These fit well under our Brio tunnels and work with the tracks perfectly. The magnetic connections are strong and keep the set together well. This set come with two train cars
and 4 accessories - the milk jug, two fences and a cow.

title: Another M&D hit
text: My 2 and 3 years olds play kitchen is well stocked with M&D food, and they love all of it. They have such great sets, and this set for making tacos doesn't disappoint. My kids always love the condiments the best, and this one is awesome since it comes with hot sauce and salsa, two we didn't previously have. The quality is great and as expected for a M&D product. It's the perfect addition for any play kitchen!

title: So fun with 3.5 year old!!
text: My daughter will be 4 in a few months, and we had so much fun playing this game twice today! It took about 15 min to play each time. Each player takes turns flipping a card over and seeing if they can add the card to an existing ice cream cone on the table. Each ice cream cone needs a cone, at least one double scoop, and a top scoop with sprinkles, so 3 cards at minimum. But in order to add a card to a stack, you need to have two matching scoops that touch - only a mint chip scoop can be added on top of a mint chip scoop, or only a top scoop of strawberry with sprinkles can be placed on top of a strawberry scoop. If you draw a card that can't currently be matched to any existing cones, that card starts a new cone. When an ice cream cone is finished by having the cone, at least 1 double scoop, and the top, the player that finishes the cone gets to pick up all the cards and place them in their ice cream truck. When you have drawn all the cards in the deck and finished as many cones as possible, each player counts the cards in their truck to see who has the most. This is a great game because it is very cooperative, working together to try to make the cones. Also all of the pieces are laying out on the table so I can help my daughter make sure she's making a correct match. It was the perfect length for holding her interest, helps with matching/pattern skills, and at the end she counted to 24 to count all of her cards, so great practice there too. Overall the perfect game for my little ice cream lover.

title: Little stickers, more suitable for 5 or 6+ year olds
text: This is a great activity for kids who love crafts, stickers, and a bit of guidance for their projects. It says ages 4+, but I have to think this is better suited for kids 5 or even 6+. My daughter is just a couple months away from 4, and she is nowhere near ready to be able to follow the sticker patterns or get the pretty small stickers in the right places. Also she would lose interest too quickly. There are so many small stickers in this that I'm sure it would take hours to complete a whole box. It is a fun idea though, especially since I like more guided projects like this! I'm sure my daughter will love it in a year or two.

title: Ramps fall off constantly, police station door won't shut
text: My 2 and 3 year old do enjoy this toy, but it's driving me crazy. When I set it up the ramp supports would not firmly click in to place. That wasn't the end of the world since the ramps still worked fine without the supports, but every single time my kids try to pick the toy up to bring it to another room or even gently bump it, both side ramps fall off from the bad connection to the station. The  back two interlocking ramps stay on fine, but the side ones do not lock in to place securely. Also the traffic cones and barriers that come with this are so tiny, they are definite choking hazards. Overall it's a cute idea, just not great quality.

title: Great fun for 3.5 year old and little brother
text: It took me about 2 hours to unbox and set this up. The instructions were straight forward and nothing was overly frustrating. After the initial 18 hour battery charge, my 3.5 year old and 2 year old hopped in and went for a test drive. My tall-ish 2 year old cannot reach the gas yet, but my 3.5 year old has no problems reaching with the seat in the furthest forward position (there are 2 positions further back for her to grow in to). She hasn't quite mastered driving in a straight line down a sidewalk, but she easily mastered shifting from forward to reverse and has fun crusing around a cul de sac. Overall the car is well engineered and feels very sturdy. I'm sure my kids will enjoy it for many years.

title: Worth about $25, Covered in glitter
text: At the time of this review, this is selling for $50, which seems very high. The quality seems acceptable, but I wouldn't describe it as high quality dress up clothes. The skirts fit my 2 and 3.5 year old fine, but the tops were big on them. The tops are labeled 4-6years, but the one pink top is so wide I cannot see it fitting my 3.5 year old for at least several years.  The other two pink/purple tops are a bit smaller, but probably wouldn't really fit my kids ideally until they were 5. I was able to use the butterfly wings to help hold the top in place on the 2 year old, and that did seem pretty effective. The set only comes with one set of wings and one wand, which isn't ideal for two kids to share, but ok. My biggest issue is the glitter. Tons and tons and tons of glitter falling off these. I'm the crazy mom who only let them wear them outside, but I'm glad because our deck is totally covered in glitter. I personally wouldn't want these in my house.

title: Harder than expected to get consistent dots
text: These are the first dot markers my 3.5 year old and I have tried. She is really enjoying them, but they don't work quite like I imagined or hoped. First, card stock or thick paper seems ideal for not letting the color bleed through, but since I didn't have any on hand I had to stack 3 pieces of normal paper to keep the color off our table. Second, they take awhile to prime. Even a couple minutes of unuse will require you to hold the marker down extra long to get the ink back in the tip. Third, even after priming you cannot move quickly with these markers - you really need to patiently, slowly, and evenly push down each dot to get a full circle. Many of my daughters dots are incomplete and even when I tried I couldn't consistently get a complete dot. Also some colors seem to work better than others. Overall my daughter still likes them, but I cannot see her using them that often or being pleased with the results as she gets older.

title: Perfect for my 2 and 3 year old!
text: My kids love Little People!! I don't know what it is about them, but they are constantly played with all over the house across all our different toys and cars and bags. This dollhouse has the perfect size rooms and furniture, it's durable and we love how it folds up. Among all of the plastic doll house choices out there, this one has to be among the top in terms of price and cuteness!

title: Great for 2 year old
text: My 2 year old loves all of the Battat toy trucks and cars. They are an amazing quality for the price point, they push great on carpet and have fun moveable parts. These are no exception. The dump truck is definitely his favorite because he loves filling it with other toys. These trucks are just slightly bigger than the similar Battat line with the cab that opens and that includes a little driver, “Battat Dump Truck Toy”. My son does have a small preference for those because he loves the little guy that comes with it, but he still loves these ones too! You can't go wrong with Battat toys.

title: 2 and 3 year olds love it
text: I had this unboxed and set up in about 20 minutes for my 2 and 3 year old to play with, and they went nuts with excitement!! They were so excited that Thomas moved along the track by himself. My 3 year old has no problems pulling back the mechanism for Thomas to fly in to the tunnel, but my just turned 2 year old cannot do it himself. He has fun resetting the palm trees, switching the turbo track sections, and watching Thomas zoom around though. We have this set up on carpet, and after awhile it must have sunken it to the carpet a bit which caused Thomas to not land properly from the jump every few times and also get stuck going on the tracks under the jump. This would work best on hard floor or a very low pile carpet. I am also a bit concerned about the long term durability of the thin plastic pieces and the jump mechanism. Also this set only comes with one train, so keep that in mind if you have multiple kids wanting to have their own. This would be a great starter trackmaster set, and you can always add more tracks and trains to create longer loops. We are already dreaming up future designs ourselves!

title: Great for 4+ years
text: My kids are both fans of the original Water Wow and were occupied for several 30 minute chunks on a recent road trip by them too. I gave this to my 3.5 year old to try, and she enjoyed coloring the pages and looking through the lens too. She needed a little help with figuring out how to use the lens, but it worked ok. There are 8 pages and each page has an activity, such as Find 8 Silly Things in the picture below. Overall she is a bit young to be able to use it exactly as intended, but that doesn't mean she can't have fun with it and use it more like the original Water Wows and color the pictures. Plus this one has more pages (8 instead of 5) and they are bigger that the original one too. I would think a 4 year old would be able to do this by themselves just fine.

title: Great for 4+ years
text: My kids are both fans of the original Water Wow and were occupied for several 30 minute chunks on a recent road trip by them too. I gave this to my 3.5 year old to try, and she enjoyed coloring the pages and looking through the lens too. She needed a little help with figuring out how to use the lens, but it worked ok. There are 8 pages and each page has an activity, such as Find 8 Silly Things in the picture below. Overall she is a bit young to be able to use it exactly as intended, but that doesn't mean she can't have fun with it and use it more like the original Water Wows and color the pictures. Plus this one has more pages (8 instead of 5) and they are bigger that the original one too. I would think a 4 year old would be able to do this by themselves just fine.

title: Mini sized Thomas fun
text: My 2 year old has gotten very in to Thomas recently, and we are fans of the wooden railway toys. This is our first experience with the Minis, and we like them! They are made out of plastic and they can connect to each other. They roll well on tile or hard wood but aren't the best at staying together on carpet since they are so small and the tiny hooks that keep them together aren't very tight or secure. They are about 1.5 inches long. I am using them for potty training rewards since they are a perfect small reward.

title: Awesome for 2 year old!
text: Like all Battat toys we have, this set is awesome. It is very similar in size/feel/build to the Battat Dump Truck Toy and the Battat Garbage Truck Toy, except that these ones do not come with drivers or cabs that open. These trucks seem to have slightly more fancy movable parts, like an excavator scoop that turns, pivots, and goes up and down. These Wonder Wheels are just a tiny bit bigger with bigger wheels as well. Between the two different lines my 2 year old has a small preference for the ones with cabs, but he still loves these cars too! They are a great quality for the price point and very colorful and engaging. My son spends 30 minutes to several hours practically every day playing with his Battat trucks!

title: A bit too loud to be perfect
text: This set is really fun and my 2 and 3 year old love it. We have never been disappointed with Battat toys, they are always a nice quality at a good price. My only issue with this teapot is that it is loud!! It plays Tea for Two, I'm a Little Teapot, and A Spoonful of Sugar. I'm the parent who is always turning the volume setting to low on toys that have two settings, but this one unfortunately only has one volume, and it's too loud. I can easily hear it from the room over. Other than that, this set is great.

title: Fun but yucky scents
text:
This product works well and as described, but my 3 year old described the smell as yucky, and I'd have to agree. It reminded me of a cherry air freshener. On top of that it is expensive. She had a lot of fun playing with it, but used up 2 of the 12 included sheets of paper in about 10 minutes,
so at this rate the paper will be used up in an hour.
I do really love the low stress of mess free color wonder products, and this would make a fun splurge/gift, but I'd personally find the scent free product instead.

title: Good quality and easy to set up
text: I had this blown up in less than 5 minutes with the help of an air mattress pump. The quality is great and I'm not overly concerned about it tearing or popping, even with it being set up on grass. I got in there with my 2 toddlers and it was the perfect size for the 3 of us!!

title: Fun for 2 year old and mom
text: This is so cute and fun!! I have to help my 2 year old, but he loves all 3 of the transformations. We love Learning Resources, and they have all been well built, quality toys!

title: A quality set you won't throw away
text: Each year I debate whether to throw away my kids cheap beach toys or to save them in the limited space I have. This set from B is a keeper for sure. The quality is so much better than typical sets you'd grab at Walmart for $6, and it stores so nicely in the bucket too. So if you intend to keep these for a few years, I'd highly recommend them. If however you don't have space or have to get rid of your set at the end of your vacation travels, I'd stay with a cheap set, because these are too nice to throw away!!

title: Great Color, texture and sounds!
text: This book has all of the fun colors, textures and sounds my kids enjoyed in books as babies. There is a squeaky crab that can be put in and out if a little pocket, a rattle turtle, and a large crinkly whale. This is a great activity for a 6-12 month old!

title: Hours of fun for 1 and 3 year old
text: We have had the Bristle Blocks Toy Building Blocks for Toddlers (128 Pieces in Bucket) for 6 months or so before adding this 75 piece twist and turn set to our collection. I have a 3 year old and a 1 year old and these are definitely one of their top 5 played with toys. They aren't necessarily building huge creations out of them, but they love making little stacks of blocks, simple little pretend airplanes, and using the blocks to fill containers and bags and move them all around the house. These twist and turn ones are fun since the shapes are a but more unique and they have funny faces as well. However, there is no lid for the container they come in, which seems ridiculous. If you are starting out with one set, I'd definitely recommend the 128 piece set that comes in the sturdy bucket with the lid.

title: Fun set
text: I love the green toys dough since it feels less crumbly and messy than play dough, and the tools are very fun, especially the spaghetti tool! I've never been disappointed with any Green Toys toy, and I have purchased a lot!

title: Small but fun
text: A bit small, but great quality and fun designs. The cover feels almost like a real book because it's so thick, instead of a typical coloring book. And the inner pages are also thick enough to use markers on. I personally wouldn't get this for my toddlers but probably for kids 6 and older.

title: Great quality and nice thickness
text: Great quality and nice thickness even for assembling on carpet. The train pattern is one of the hardest 24 piece puzzles we have due to the colors and way it was cut, but my 3 year old loves it all the same.

title: Great quality and size
text: I purchased the original green and yellow watering can in the past for gifts and my own kids. My kids use it outside in the summer and in the bath tub without the lid/rope in the winter. We have noticed the rope getting gross and moldy after time, but you can remove the lid or cut out the rope if you want. It's the perfect size for my 1 and 3 year old, and they love playing with the watering can and the shovel!

title: Thick plastic and perfect size
text: I purchased the original green and yellow watering can in the past for gifts and my own kids. My kids use it outside in the summer and in the bath tub without the lid/rope in the winter. We have noticed the rope getting gross and moldy after time, but you can remove the lid or cut out the rope if you want. It's the perfect size for my 1 and 3 year old, and they love playing with the watering can and the shovel!

title: Adorable fun for traveling
text:
These are adorable. The little travelers set has enough pieces to make 8 girls (no boy faces on this set). It also has a couple accessories like a guitar, purse, dog and luggage. You can really only fit 4 of the girls on the scenes at a time, so for traveling I'm going to put all of the pieces inside a ziplock bag so my daughter can use both sides of the tin instead of having to store the unused pieces on one side of it. The animal band set is fun too, but there is clearly a correct match when matching the animals heads and feet, so it's not quite as fun as the travelers in my opinion.
I got these for my daughter to play with on an airplane, and they will be perfect. It seems like it would make a great gift for a 3-5 year old!

title: Perfect for 3 and 1.5 yr old
text: My kids, 1.5 and 3, have so much fun playing with this! I was surprised by the soft, pliable dough, and may find myself switching from play doh in the future for this kind instead. This Green Toys dough is softer, easier to roll out, and a bit less crumbly/messy. The flower cutters are cute, and there is also a tool that makes spaghetti noodles, and though I'm not exactly sure why that relevant to flowers, it's fun. I only wish it came with more than three dough colors!

title: Fun but expensive
text: Nice quality wooden train. It plays a fun little tune and it's not too loud to be super annoying. The current price point of $20 seems high.

title: Good but not great
text: Good puzzle and I like the world map for teaching, but not as thick, sturdy or nice as The Learning Journey puzzles we have! TLJ ones exceed this brand. These ones are a bit thinner and harder to lock the pieces together, especially on carpet.

title: Good quality, great for toddlers
text: These letters are a great size for my 1 and 3 year old. You get 2 of every lowercase and 2 of every uppercase letter, which is great for being able to spell more words and names. They are made of thick foam that does not bend easily, and after a week of playing with them and walking on the ones spread all over the floor, they are still in the same condition. The carrying case that they come in is pretty cheap and flimsy, like a thin shoe boxed size container you could get at a dollar store, but it gets the job done.

title: Well built and colorful
text: Fun for a 1 and 3 year old!

title: Great for Glitter Girls or Wellie Wishers
text: My daughter has a Glitter Girl and a Wellie Wisher, and this fits both (14inch dolls). The quality is great for the price. I find genuine WW clothes from American Girl to be just slightly nicer, but these clothes are still very nice and inexpensive in comparison! All shoes and clothes are interchangeable. See picture for GG in the equestrian outfit we received, plus a side by side GG and WW in their original outfits.

title: Super cute, same quality as Wellie Wishers
text: The quality feels identical to my daughter's Wellie Wisher, at 1/3 the price!! This Battat doll is super cute and pretty. Her hair feels the same as the WW. The outfit and shoes have a very similar feel as well. See the picture for the Battat doll on the left and the WW on the right. I switched the shoes on them and they both fit each other. The clothes also fit each other. Both brands joints and heads move similarly, and neither dolls eyes close (unlike full sized American Girls). Basically both brands really do feel the same, it just comes down to a matter of which features/outfit you prefer!

title: Bought three, all great
text: We purchased two for our kids and one for a gift and all have worked perfectly. They aren't the thickest/sturdiest plastic housing, but they seem perfectly fine. You also need to make sure to fully screw the lid back in to place after putting in batteries for it to work. I'm wondering if some people with bad reviews just didn't get it in place properly. I'd recommend trying it, and if you get a dud, Amazon will take care of you!

title: Tattoos last weeks!!
text: My 2 year old has now tried two of these on her forearms. The first one was on for two solid weeks before I scrubbed it off in the bath. The second one has also been on two weeks and is still there. It has faded, but you can still tell it's Dory. They apply easily and the colors are nice. Overall a great experience and value for us!

title: Love Tegu Blocks
text:
I love playing with Tegu blocks with my kids. These and Magna Tiles are the toys I get most excited about, and the kids love them too. We got the 42 piece set back in the spring, and we have a Tegu monster and a whale, and this makes a great addition. Each block has a very nice feel, is smooth, and nicely painted in bright colors. The magnets are totally enclosed - no choking hazards here - and are very strong! It does take a while to get used to building with the magnets since the polar forces create a right side and a wrong side when you are trying to connect them. For that reason, although even my 1 year enjoys playing with them, kids will probably be best with these when they are 4 or older.
This expansion, with all of the columns, cubes and planks, is great for having the necessary pieces to stabilize most creations. (This set does NOT come with any angled pieces or wheels that come in the 42 piece set)
They are definitely pricey, but they really are top notch quality, and really all magnetic toys are on the expensive side. I feel the price is justified for such a well built, reinvented classic toy that will last for years.

title: Fun addition to existing Tegu collection
text: We are fans of Tegu blocks, and they are a great toy for parents as well as kids. My kids, ages 1 and 2 enjoy playing with them, although I expect the experience will be much better when the kids are 4-8 and can better understand the magnetic forces. We have bought several larger sets prior to receiving this one, and even though they are pricey, the quality is great and magnetic toys are typically expensive. I feel the price is warranted. This set is fun, but it is very small so the opportunities of things to build are limited. If you are considering adding it to other blocks, I would recommend it. If you are looking for a travel set, I would instead recommend the pocket pouches that come in a carrying case since these don't have a case. And if you don't have any Tegu blocks at all, I'd recommend trying some because they're great, but you can do much more with the 14 piece set.

title: Good for inexpensive price point
text: This toolbox gets 3.5 stars... on the one hand, the plastic tools are somewhat cheap. They aren't a nice quality plastic. On the other hand, this is only $16 right now, so the quality seems reasonable for that price point. The tool box itself is actually really nice, thick, sturdy and huge. It's the size of real tool boxes and definitely the nicest part of this product. And the tape measure is pretty cute. The tape pulls out like real tape measures and is 3 feet long. You hand wind it back up. The hammer, saw, and remaining pieces feel a smidge cheap, lightweight and not very durable. The colors are bright and attractive. Overall for the price this is a good set and likely intended for toddlers and very young children, but I have also seen much nicer sets in the $40 price range.

title: So much fun
text: My 1 and 2 year old and I have been playing with these the past week, and they are so much fun! My 2.5 year old is good at putting them together and the 1 year old likes destroying the creations. To make anything specific like the house or car pictured on the bucket, you actually need to have some foresight in lining the pieces up-- certain sides have one row of prongs and the opposite sides have two rows, so there is actually a specific orientation that the blocks need to be in to line up many in a row or connect them in specific patterns. I would guess maybe a 4 or 5 year old may be able to do this themself? But for now my 2.5 year old just likes stacking them in towers and she really enjoys the flowers and animals too. 128 pieces gives you tons of options of things to do and build, and I think the price is very reasonable for a toy that will likely last forever. There aren't any pieces to break or deteriorate, the biggest thing you need to worry about is losing them or stepping on them!

title: Fun addition for play kitchen
text: Fun set of 5 juices for my 1 and 2 year olds play kitchen. They say "disappearing" in the package, but when turned upside down, the bottle still appears half full. Not a big deal, I just found it interesting. Also the bottles are wrapped with paper labels, so if you have a baby crawling around and chewing on things, they may get ruined quickly. The lids are also glued in place and not removable. They are colorful, sturdy plastic and about 8 inches tall. My kids are enjoying pretending pouring them in to cups and carrying them around!

title: Awesome truck at great price
text: This truck is made of thick, durable plastic. The cab opens to remove the driver. It's easily pushed on carpet and hard floors. And it is so inexpensive! We also have the dump truck and we will probably add the cement truck to our collection next. Great for my 1 year old and 2 year old!

title: Not our favorite M&D play food
text: We have a play kitchen fully stocked with Melissa and Doug play food, and we love most of it. This however, is not the best. The set comes with resealable plastic bags for each of the freezer foods, but there are only two pieces of each food. So only two wooden blueberry clusters go in the frozen blueberry bag. Moreover, the food doesn't look realistic at all. The wooden blueberries look like a blue blob, I originally thought the chicken tenders were potatoes... they are just all very boring, flat, and lacking any special design or texture. Not our favorite, but the kids will still enjoy it once they've already pulled out all the other food and this is the only thing left to make a mess of. :)

title: Love this classic game
text: Yes! The same version I played as a kid is back in this retro Guess Who. I had purchased the new version with the smaller square box about 8 years ago, and that one is ok, but everything felt cheaper and cartoonish. This is the classic game I know and love!

title: Durable, quality toy
text: These are brightly colored and very durable. My kids enjoy pushing the cars around and rearranging them on the carrier. The quality is great and we love the feel of the sturdy, thick cars. We've never been disappointed with any Green Toys!

title: Awesome wagon for 1.5 - 3 years
text: This wagon is awesome for my 2 year old! It is very sturdy and durable, and we love the solid feel of it. Because it is rather small, I'm guessing the usable life on this will be on the short end. I doubt my toddler will want to play with it by the time she's 3, maybe 3.5. It seems perfect for 18 months - 3 years, but probably not much longer. Therefore only 4 stars.

title: Fun kitchen toy
text:
A great addition for any play kitchen! The quality is good, as expected from M&D products, and seems appropriate for the price point too. The syrup and milk dispensers are similar to play baby bottles where the liquids seem to disappear when tilted. I was concerned the jam containers might be paper or that the lids may be choking hazards, but they are decently sturdy plastic and big enough that I feel ok with my baby being around them.
Overall a fun toy!

title: Traditionalist Parent Approved
text:
I generally don't prefer electronic learning, but these are pretty cool. The Smart Letters each have three rubber feet that are spaced differently, and the tablet recognizes the letter when you gently place it on the tablet screen. It took about 10 minutes to download all 6 free apps (3 for letters, 3 for numbers) and to set up the quick profile. The apps are simple to use and well designed. Next is a summary of the 3 letter apps:

Bla Bla Box: spell out words and hear them read back to you
Alphamonster: choose a letter to hear the sound the letter makes and see a picture of a word beginning with that letter. See a picture of an item and identify what letter the item starts with. Hear a sound of a letter and identify the letter. See a cursive lowercase letter and identity the matching wooden uppercase letter. (In the settings you can pick which letters will appear throughout these challenges. The default is the entire alphabet but you can pick just a few if your child needs to focus on certain letters)
Vocabubble: game 1- pick any letter and as you repeatedly place the letter on the tablet, 8 different pictures of items beginning with that letter will fall down the screen. Game 2 - choose two letters, then pictures of items beginning with those two letters will fall down the screen and you tap the picture with the right letter in order for it to disappear. (This was a fun game my niece and nephew enjoyed playing together as they each held a letter. However, some pictures seemed too hard or random for a 5 year old, such as an Orca for the letter O... kids will think it's a Whale... or a Totem Pole or Quaill, etc)

My five year old niece and nephew enjoyed testing these for me and were definitely interested in the games. I'm excited to start my daughter with it when she turns three and I can see the number apps extending the usefulness of the product as she gets older. Four stars, not five, only because they do seem a bit pricey and also because the accent on the American English setting we tried out is a bit odd at times.

title: Great quality and perfect size
text: My 2 year old received this for Christmas and we love it! There is just enough room on the tray to fit a small cup and snack bowl, or play food and play dishes. All of her stuffed animals fit great in the seat too. The chair is sturdy and the wood and paint still look exactly as they did when we set it up three months ago. I'm sure it will hold up well for a long time. I'd definitely recommend it!

title: Highly useful expansion pack
text:
We got the set of 100 magna tiles and I was trying to figure out what to add to our collection. I read some reviews that the polygon set wasnt very compatible with the squares and triangles included in the normal sets (hexagons would have been more compatible) and therefore you really would need a couple of the pentagon sets to be able to use them all together, because otherwise 8 pieces aren't enough to do anything with.
We opted for this rectangle set instead, and it is great. The four big squares are helpful for stabilizing most creations, and even as they joined the 4 we got in the 100 piece set, I feel as if we could still use more of these. I wasn't sure how useful the rectangles would be because you could obviously just use two small squares. But they are really helpful in making doors and windows easily (see photo).
Overall a great expansion. We will probably get another soon!

title: Fun set
text:
My just turned 2 year old and I had fun playing with this. This was her first time playing with play doh and she enjoyed it a lot! It does seem like a 2.5 or 3 year old would be able to more fully enjoy this and roll out the dough and use the cutters themselves. (And if I had to guess kids over 5 would be too old for this simple set)

If this set is currently around $15, we'd recommend it. (Its hard to rate with Amazons price fluctuations, but it was oringally $35, which I'd say is way overpriced) You get 6 tiny containers of play doh that would cost maybe $3 at Target, 8 small plastic cutters, a plastic knife, a plastic rolling pin, plastic tongs, 3 plastic graduated cylinders, a small plastic stylus, and 3 paper activity sheets. It also comes with some suggested instructions on how to use the paper activity sheets.

It is a fun set and I think it would also make a great birthday gift, but you could probably also buy a bigger set of play doh and a set of cutters and use your imagination to create scientific activities if you were so inclined.

title: Great toy for parents and kids
text:
This block set is super fun! The blocks are high quality with strong magnets that are easy for my almost 2 year old to put together and take apart. I'm pretty sure I have more fun playing with them than her at this point, but that's fine with me! I will most likely end up buying us a bigger set of these since you can only do so much with one small set.

I would give 5 stars if they were a little less expensive and if they came with some sort of storage bag or box. I think they are a little overpriced, but we still love them and will purchase more in the future.

title: Good choice

title: Music broken on 2nd Lamb

title: Fun and soft
text: We love Habas soft food! With babies around, we prefer this over hard wood that will inevitably be chewed and then chip. These pieces are big enough they don't pose choking hazards, and the knife isn't too rough or sharp either. All around fun.

title: Like most M&D products we've tried
text: Like most M&D products we've tried, this is awesome! It is made of bright and solid wood pieces that are large enough the whole family can play with them. This set is similar to the slice and bake cookie set we play with where you can mix and match the pieces for many popsicle and cookie sandwich combinations. These definitely hold their interest longer than other wooden play food that comes 'as is.' The only possible drawback is the additional pieces to clean up!

title: Soft and adorable
text: So soft and cuddly! Great size for small toddlers- it's the perfect size for my 20 month old to tuck under her arm. Its legs and arms are cute and floppy and there are beans in the feet and bottom giving it nice weight. Overall very cute and cozy!

title: Fun toy for young car enthusiasts
text: This truck is a lot of fun! For little ones that love cars, they should be able to help build it from age 4+. The finished product isn't extremely high quality and can come apart easily, but therein is the fun of building it again. If you are looking for a high quality fire engine to simply push around, the green toys one is awesome. This one is a lot of fun for the model building though. Be aware that there are small pieces if you have younger kids as well!!

title: Reasonably priced, quality bounce house!
text: Great toy for our basement on hot and cold days with the added bonus of great white noise for colicky newborn! After a few months it still looks new, and it seems very likely to hold up to a good 5 years or so of use!

title: MISSING PIECES
text: Fun design for a puzzle with a good number of pieces.... Yet we had two duplicate (extra) pieces and it was missing three pieces! Called the puzzle company that basically said that's how it is and sometimes they come out of the puzzle cutter like that. We just finished the Snow White puzzle which also had an extra piece, implying someone else was missing that one for their puzzle. POOR QUALITY CONTROL. I do not recommend this brand.

title: TOTAL WASTE OF TIME AND MONEY
text:
I don't know what age this would appropriate for. A child who knows numbers will be frustrated by the 1-5 and 6-10 buttons, and it is useless for a child trying to learn numbers.

What touch screen? The top half does absolutely nothing and the mirror is so small it's useless.

What volume control? There is none.

This product is not a good advertisement for Fisher-Price.

title: Great!
text:
The only reason I gave it one star is that the handle isn't removable. I understand this is a carrying case, but the option to remove the handle would've been nice when the case is stored at home.

But everything else is great. These hold my yo-yos (not enough to fill the case) perfectly. The case comes with pre-cut foam. At first, the holes seemed a bit small. But inserting a yo-yo showed that they fit perfectly; there's a bit of snug, but only enough to prevent the yo-yos from falling out. The zippered storage area is narrow but just enough for strings, bearings, lube, and tools.

title: No piano sounds, but still fun.
text:
For some reason I thought this would have different tones for each magnet; instead, they just click when they're moved. The toy is a lot of fun, though. Shockingly, actually. This is something that can be kept in a pocket and played with; I had mine in my jacket and would play with it by making different patterns with my thumb.

The pieces can be removed to alternate the layout, but the magnets are strong and won't come off easily.

title: Good but difficult to clean.
text: Nice, pasty paints that smear onto painting pages pretty nicely. They are a bit difficult to clean from paint trays, but some scrubbing gets 'em off eventually.

title: Great toys.
text:
The kids have had this for a few months now and they get played with during each bath. I've noticed no mold on them, but we wipe them down anyway.

The squirt power is a bit weak on some, but overall they're well-made toys.

title: Frustrating for my kids
text: We couldn't figure out the ‘magic' of this coloring book. My kids used it like any other coloring book and art supplies. I wouldn't recommend purchasing it.

title: Great four-pack.
text:
Great scissors for crafts. They fit perfectly in our six-year-old's and ten-year-old's hands. The sheaths are nice to cover while they're not in use; there's a little nub that prevents the sheath from slipping off of its own volition, but it's very easy to take out by little hands.

The blades are dull but still provide a good cut. There's a righty and a lefty in our family, and neither have complained about comfort.

title: Fun activity- not reusable
text: Our family went on a road trip for the week of Thanksgiving. These stickers kept my kids (6,10) busy during the trip. The only issue we had is they aren't reusable. You can easily remove them but they don't re-stick to another surface.

title: Great first speedcube.
text:
When I got this, I still didn't solve the Rubik's cube. I know there are all kinds of tutorials, but I wanted to solve it on my own. Fast-forward 11 years later, I flipped the table (so to speak) and watched a couple tutorials. This was the cube I used to solve the puzzle for the first time. I watched a couple videos of the cube before receiving mine to get a better understanding of the mechanisms and design. During my first session, I set the magnets to the strongest and left the dials as they were. Two hours is how long it took me to solve it on the first try.

I like that this cube comes with a handful of accessories. I use the case to carry the cube with me to and from work. It stays on my desk; whenever I have to read something on my monitors and not use the keyboard, I solve a little bit. Now I can solve the cube in minutes, though it took me a few days to get to this point. I now have the spring and tension set to the strongest for how much force can be pulled and weakest for how fast turns can be. (Apologies for not using the correct terms, but I tried looking up what the dials exactly do and I still can't figure out which does what with regard to the terminology, but I base it off feel.)

The cube comes with a leather bag and a tool to adjust the magnets. The first time I accessed the dials, I used a pen to pop off the tiles. They can be difficult to pull off by hand alone, even after being pulled so many times. The lever for each dial also was difficult to pull. Now, I leave it semi-flush to the dial to make it easier to access in the future. They also pop off easily, but are [somewhat] easy to put back. The magnet levels sometimes move on their own. If I happen to notice a magnet at a strength I didn't set it at, I'll re-adjust. Annoying, but an easy fix. I no longer use the tool that came with the cube because any item small and flat enough will work. The bag is kept in the box for now.

There are two manuals that come with the cube: one for the cube itself and the other on how to solve it. I tried using the solve tutorial but found it confusing with some typographical errors, so I used videos. I learn better visually anyway. Even though the cube's manual has great illustrations for the mechanics, I failed to understand what they actually do, so I looked up videos for that too.

This is the third cube I own and currently it's my favorite. Each time my time lowers after solving, I adjust the settings. I'm becoming a speedcuber without realizing it.

title: In a word, fun. In another word, frustrating. In a new word, funstrating.
text:
The first TCG I was hooked on was Pokémon, which was about 10 years ago. I grew up with the Pokécraze in the 90s, and still collect the cards. Thankfully, I full unlimited sets of the first three sets. Over time, and of course with life's changes and demands, I stopped playing the game. Thank goodness, too, because what a money sink that can be. I played MtG for a bit, but thankfully convinced myself to stop playing because of the money factor alone. But I still love playing card games because of the physical cards and the resource management. Then I discovered Fantasy Flight's LCGs. I got into tabletop games from Europe before TCGs, so I was familiar with Fantasy Flight. I found out about their Lord of the Rings Card Game when it was first announced, but didn't bother to understand what an LCG was. With the pandemic, my interest in tabletop games peaked, but I still didn't want to get into TCGs. Then I was reminded of this game with the re-release and ordered the Core Set. What a wise choice.

The rules are a beast to master, but they are clear and guide you with a comforting hand without feeling like they're holding your hand like it's a child's. If ever I was confused, all I had to do was look in another section of the manual and my confusion dissipated. To start, the game comes in that oh-so-ever-nice cardboard box Fantasy Flight games are known for. Upon opening, the game greets you with the rule book, an instruction guide, sheets of tokens and build-your-own life counters (Who doesn't live opening those fresh token sheets and popping them out?!) and a plastic insert with the sealed cards. What did I do next? Go to Board Game Geek and look up sweet printables the community made. Using the insert alone, I was able to organize the cards in a utilitarian manner. While the tokens and life counters provided are nice, I used third-party options that I'll explain later below.

Finally, I sat down one night, blocked off two hours, and opened the instruction manual. The manual gives four starter decks to build. I built each played each against the first scenario. The first game took me the full two hours due to the learning curve. There's definitely a lot to keep track of. The game uses some mechanics from other TCGs, but does so in a way that makes it feel like I'm actually in a Middle-earth adventure. Almost like a choose-your-own adventure. Because the game can be played solo, I took my time to absorb every step and read each card's text in full. I know there can be only so much text on the small cards, but the font is *teeny*. The game certainly needs a well-lit table.

After I tested each deck, I moved on to the next scenario, which helped me nearly memorize all the steps. To this day, I sometimes forget a step, so I made my own mini rule book that fits inside a deck box. (By the way, I use an Ultimate Guard Twin Flip'n'Tray, which comfortably holds two decks and the scenario deck--all double-sleeved--a handful of dividers, and two slim life counters.) Once I got to the third scenario, though, I hit a block. Another reason I steered clear from TCGs is the process of deck-building. It's long, tedious, and I just don't want to use what little time and memory I have to maintain decks. Thankfully, the years before the re-release have seen lots of contributions from the community. I recommend going to the game's Subreddit, which provides extremely useful and informative links on deck-building and steps for beginners. With Beorn's Path, I finally found fantastic decks to crush the third scenario--mostly. It's still a monster. Before the third scenario, I was hesitant on using more than one deck while playing solo. Keeping track of all those steps twice intimidated me, but I realized playing the third scenario with just one is impossible and only will cause you torment. Plus, there are mechanics that are available only with more than one deck. Once I confronted my fear, I soon realized how much more fun I was missing out on from using only one deck. The game does a wonderful job at incorporating other players.

The game is fun, but can be frustrating. Some enemies are obscenely strong, and the rules (if followed strictly, which I do) can be unforgiving to follow. Playing a scenario for two hours or more only to lose makes for a frustrating experience. I thought finally beating the third scenario would be cathartic, but it was underwhelming. I won! ...Yay... The only prize was putting all those parts away.

Now for the accessories. If a game has a good following on Board Game Geek, chances are the community will make fun accessories or suggestions of accessories to use. LotR: LCG utilizes turning the cards and tokens to show certain choices made throughout the game. This became a tedious process and quite messy; moving all those parts every step became a burden. Plus, the game needs a *lot* of table space. After consulting the internet and performing my own trials and errors, I've come to the setup in the picture attached to this review.

- d20 for first-player token and round count
- Thin, plastic life counters that I can store in the deck box
- White and black stones for unperformed actions
- Small d6 for anything requiring numbers (life, quest progress, resource, etc.)
- d10 for heads/tails and randomizer
- Wooden card stand for staging area (optional, but helps)
- Large mouse pad for gaming area; I didn't like the large options game companies offer, and found that a large mouse pad met the size I needed and is very inexpensive compared to “official” options
- Deck box trays to hold player cards and unused tokens
- Beverage and edible optional, but strongly recommended

This may seem to cause confusion, but this is what helps me keep track of every possible option in the game without getting lost or having to move a lot of cards/pieces compared to what's in the box. Yes, it adds more cost to the game, but it's completely optional. While this provides what I require for the Core Set, I will amend or append as necessary with each expansion.

I finally found a card game I can play on my own and enjoy without having to pay big bucks.

Note: If any of the review is confusing, please let me know. I never edit my reviews, but am more than happy to help.

title: My girls loved this set!
text: So many markers! My girls have loved using these markers. It's nice that there are several markers for each color so my girls don't fight over the individual markers. My 10 year old is really motivated to ensure all the colors remain in their designated spot.

title: Not very durable, frustrating for my 6 and 10 year olds
text: I was hoping this would be the Frozen version of the Lets Go Fishing game which lasted our family years. However, my 6 and 10 year olds were very frustrated when playing this game. They had trouble retrieving the snowflakes from the game.

title: So many options in this drawing set!
text: There are so many different options in this drawing set (see photo attached). My six year old daughter really enjoys arts and crafts so she was thrilled to have her own set of markers, pens, pencils, and notebook. Great gift option.

title: Great activity to keep kids busy
text:
We recently went on a family road trip and this was a great activity to keep my 6 and 10 year olds busy so they didn't get consumed by screens the entire time.
The kit comes with quite a few scratch pages along with stencils and wooden pens.
We are used to the scratch paper so we were prepared but it's important to note that it gets pretty messy as you scratch off the top layer to reveal the bottom layer.

title: Worked well for a road trip
text: The listing for the doodle book indicates it is for 3-5 year olds. However, my 6 year old really enjoyed this activity bag and doodle book on a recent family road trip. It came with stickers, stencils, and rainbow scratch paper. I would highly recommend this to any parent looking to keep their young children occupied, whether on a road trip or at home.

title: Perfect gift for pre teen
text: My ten year old daughter has been BEGGING me for a DIY journal kit and this fit the bill. It provides her with options to personalize her journal which allows her to express her creativity. I would highly recommend this for a gift for your preteen.

title: MINE.
text:
I don't know why I thought this wouldn't be a disaster between my daughters. I ordered one and thought, "Maybe they'll share this one." Pff...

So now it's mine and they have to ask for permission to handle; this way, I make sure each has the right amount of time to hold it. It's very soft and cuddly. It's not as soft as the name-brand ones, but it's still very loveable. I wish the feet were made of a better material; they're flat, but I'm sure they'll remain sturdy and stitched to the body. Currently, it rests on our lounger seat and it takes up most of the cushion. It's a great Thanksgiving decoration and a hit in our home.

title: Fun for a novice!
text:
There was one summer in the very end of the 90s that I got into yo-yos. They boomed at my elementary school--so much so that eventually they were banned. After that ban, I wanted to see the fuss. I didn't get into them right away because many of my classmates were learning more advanced tricks by the time I realized the hype, and I figured I'd never get to that level. But during one fateful summer, away from the city for the whole season, I practiced on my own. I learned a few tricks, but that was it.

Fast-forward and I'm now seeing these toys more frequently downtown Chicago. From children to adults, the popularity is back. I did some research to see where I left off (quite a lot has happened), and looked up beginner-friendly yo-yos. I ordered this one and it's been played with daily since it arrived. It's very easy to use for someone like me who hasn't touched one in 20 years. There are different strings available, so no need to stress on back-ups just yet. There is also a bearing for an unresponsive mod, but I'm not there yet. So far, I've been able to re-do most of the tricks I learned, and I'm happy to see what else I'll learn with this one.

title: Fun and clean.
text:
Haven't played with a yo-yo in about 20 years, so I was excited to see the advancement in technology. I found that MagicYoYo was a good brand, so I ordered two yo-yos--one metal, and this one. I love the clear look, and wanted a plastic one. Back in the day, I had only one butterfly-type yo-yo. While I prefer the more traditional shapes, a good butterfly is nice to have around.

This one is geared more toward children. The metal one I have, V3, spins longer when suspended. This clear one comes back more easily; my kids love playing with this one more. Even though both this and the V3 currently have responsive bearings, the V3 plays nicer for those with intermediate skills. Now, I don't have intermediate skills in the slightest; I can walk the dog and throw it in the air, but that's it. But, seeing all these cool features in modern yo-yos, I'll probably learn more.

title: I hate slime but my kids love it
text: My kids absolutely love slime but it is honestly my worst nightmare. As a parent I was not looking forward to having this kit in my home especially since there are so many pieces and the decorations made a HUGE mess. However, my kids loved it. There are so many mini slime containers that my daughter enjoyed handing a few out to her closest friends. If you don't mind the mess, it's a nice activity to keep the kids busy.

title: Cute makeup kit for little ones
text: My daughter is five years old and loves watching me get ready in the morning. I can't even count how many times she asks me to do her makeup or paint her nails. This was the perfect kit to appease her makeup fantasies. It would also make a great birthday gift. I wouldn't recommend for anyone younger than 3 or 4 years old.

title: Cheap...cheap.
text: I've never had darts clog Nerf guns until this one. I've had to rip them out, yank them, and pry them from the barrel. The only reason I gave it two stars is for the price.

title: Feels amazing, but the white overpowers the die.
text: Amazing die that feels well-made and weighty. I love the patterns placed inside. However, the one I received is overpowered by white. When I looked at the image, I thought the white wouldn't be the dominant the color and, wherever it was, that it would be more translucent. The one I have is mostly the white color and is more opaque in person. Still an awesome die.

title: Family fun that sparks connection
text: The past two years in this pandemic have caused increased tension in our family unit. Being near each other in a small apartment is bound to drive anyone nuts. I have been looking for creative ways to engage and connect with my husband and two young kids (5, 9). This book was a great addition to our routine and has created opportunities to spark connection. It engages both of our kids and they get excited to see what the next activity is going to be. I highly recommend every family try this out.

title: Chessex dice.
text: Standard 12mm Chessex cube. Got these to go with my LotR LCG theme. They work wonderfully. I did notice that some dice had scuffs, so I wonder whether this was a return. Still, it's Chessex, so you know what to expect.

title: Wonderful for LCG.
text:
I ordered this deck box for the sole purpose of carrying my LCG decks. I currently play The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game, and wanted a large enough deck box to hold two player decks and the encounter deck. The current quest I'm playing is the final of the Core Set. This deck box holds all the decks and tokens wonderfully.

The two player decks comprise about 100 cards, which I have double-sleeved using Dragon Shield Perfect Fit and Dragon Shield Matte sleeves. One player deck and half of the other fits completely in one card tray. The other card tray houses the other half of the second player deck, the encounter deck, the threat dials, a handful of Ultimate Guard card dividers, a Fisher Space pen and a few sheets of paper I use for various purposes. The token tray houses normal-sized d10 and d20, as well as a small dice bag filled with Chessex stones and 10mm dice. The petrol color is awesome and my favorite of the Twin Flip'n'Tray options.

Though I keep the deck box at home, I imagine it will be sturdy on the move. I was worried about the magnets inadvertently loosening, but they are snappy and secure. The Professor knows what he's talking about. However, after watching some of The Professor's reviews on Gamegenic current offerings, I'm very intrigued. I don't have complaints with Ultimate Guard's non-removable flaps; I never even considered a company would make them removable.

title: Quality for the price.
text:
I don't use these for DnD. Rather, I use them for an LCG I've been playing. The polygonal set works perfectly for my various rolling and token needs.

For the price, these are pretty good. I know there are nicer metal sets that cost way more, but these fit my needs for now. They don't bounce when I roll them; since I'm not too concerned with randomness right now, I love that they just fall onto the playmat with no secondary movement. The numbers are easy to read, though the "1" sometimes gets mistaken for a "7." They come with a leather-feeling (not sure whether real leather) bag and a case. Each die came in an individual plastic bag, which is a nice gesture from the manufacturer that prevents scuffing during shipment.

title: Easter hit!
text: These were wonderful to add to the Easter baskets. We filled the baskets and saved these eggs for last; they were perfect as they filled all necessary space and each child received an equal amount. The plastic eggs are sturdier than the typical, disposable eggs sold in stores. The sand can be a bit messy to clean at times, but many kids' toys are. The sand certainly is kinetic and the kids love making shapes with them. They also pair well with Play-Doh accessories.

title: Quality is diminishing, but still good.
text: Fun little pack of vehicles and people. I will say that this set is a drop in quality compared to our other toys. We've accumulated LP toys and sets over the years, and they've been high quality stuff. There is very little screen-printing, which, from my experience, is relegated to play sets. However, the figures and vehicles in this set are screen-printed. All the other figures and vehicles are molded, with a handful of stickers. The plastic also feels a little less durable.

title: Awesome upgrade!
text:
I ordered this to upgrade from the lightsaber I previously had. While it was fine, there were some things I found lacking. The voice feedback to indicate which sound font was used was annoying, and some colors didn't seem vibrant. While this lightsaber is from the same company and only a year newer, there definitely are improvements.

The colors actually look like what they're supposed to be. Even though there's only one button, the button combos do a lot. They can change the colors immediately, or have a rainbow cycle. I prefer the former as sometimes the rainbow cycle doesn't stop when I'd like. With the previous lightsaber, there weren't any fixed lights like there are here.

Another thing I like is the uniform voice to indicate which sound font is being used. With the previous lightsaber, voices from films or shows were used, which sounded cheap to me. This lightsaber uses one male voice for all, but the sound fonts don't say the characters' names, only a theme surrounding them (but they're easy to tell whose is being used).

While this lightsaber doesn't include music from the movies (my old one did), it's not something I miss. I never played the music and found it odd on a lightsaber.

title: Pricey, but nice.
text:
Pricey for the amount of chips they store. One-hundred chips is not a lot. This amount of chips will cover speed games and no more. If you want storage capacity for a full game of poker, you'll need way more chips.

The wood is nice, but I wonder about the manufacturig process. The wood feels light in the hands. Still, it protects the chips handsomely.

title: Easy to pick up, somewhat of a pain to disassemble.
text:
The game is easy enough for anyone to play, and adds challenge for any age. My five-year-old understood the rules immediately, and my nine-year-old became competitive just as quickly. As a much older person, I understood the mechanics but still had a challenge. It requires dexterity and speed; with two people doing the same thing, the game is bound to be fun and challenging for many.

The box is a bit bigger than many game boxes, but no space is wasted. Everything is neatly packed, so there's zero airspace. That's great, but it also poses a problem if you have limited tabletop space. Because the box is tight, everything must be disassembled and placed in specific ways so the box stays closed. This is fine long-term, but if you want to pick this game up on a routine basis, and it isn't possible to just leave it on the table, then it's somewhat of a pain. That, coupled with the fact we have a cat; the basketballs remain exposed, and the cat loves to play.

Otherwise, I'm shocked at how budget-friendly this game is. It's certainly one of our favorite games to play with children in a wide age range (when we actually have the game out, that is).

title: Fine until the battery dies.
text:
This is my first lightsaber in about a decade. The last one I owned what a Force FX by Hasbro; my, how technology has evolved.

This lightsaber is cheaper than the one I purchase, yet has a lot more to offer. While it doesn't have the "expanding" lights (it's sort of like a flashlight), the features it has make up for it. There's only one button, yet it does so much. Initial long press wakes it up or puts it to sleep. While it's on standby, there are button sequences that control music, volume, and sound font.

With the light emitted, the lightsaber has clash functionality, and the ability to change colors. What I love about changing colors is that the colors cycle in a rainbow fashion; there is no predetermined number of colors. See a color you like between cycles? Stop on it and it stays. Pretty nice.

The smooth swing works effectively, but the sound doesn't fade away; instead, there's an abrupt stop. So if you turn the lightsaber one way, the sound follows in synchronization, but immediately stops. It sort of takes away from the effect, but I imagine lightsabers with better smooth-swing functionality have better accuracy.

One day, while charging the lightsaber after a month, the charging sound came on and kept announcing the charging state. I was a little concerned, but left it. Suddenly, the sound was rapid, then silence. I checked the lightsaber and the charging light wasn't on. I tried different outlets, but no fix. Thankfully, the lightsaber is easy to disassemble, so I checked out the battery. It seems fine, but I am awaiting a new one to make sure it's just the battery that was fried.

title: Fine, but a bit overpriced and requires mutliple swipes to clear.
text: Simple tablet that does what it does and nothing more. It comes with a stylus to bring out the rainbow colors, and a slot to hold the templates. The plastic feels brittle to me, but my daughter is fine with it. One thing I noticed is that the drawings don't clear upon first swipe. It may take two or more swipes to clear.

title: Still lots of fun.
text:
Still made well and fun to use. I gave my daughters each one; one lasted, the other went through some brutal missions. I keep one at my desk as a fidget toy and the bouncing movements help me relax.

Good, ol' Slinky.

title: Excellent saber for smaller hands.
text:
Great saber for kids. I have a larger, smooth-swing saber that's meant for adult hands, but this one is about 2/3 of the size. It cuts down the metal to make it more comfortable for kids to hold. With that in mind, some other features make it easier for kids to handle.

The single button powers the saber on and off, and also changes the colors. My larger saber requires certain button combinations to change the colors (because it also has different sounds and features), whereas this requires a long press to power on and off, and a single, quick press to change colors when on. The only things I wish this had is sound selection. There's only one sound.

Also, there's no smooth swing, but it works well enough for kids. The blade is shorter than the standard length, but very durable.

title: Very nice.
text: Super addition to our Melissa & Doug dollhouse. Fits perfectly and is pretty sturdy. Most of the M&D furniture we've purchased already is broken, but this crib still is in tiptop shape.

title: Fun!
text: Loads of fun and works great. The dinosaur feels a bit cheap, but sturdy enough to withstand normal bumps against walls.

title: Nice gift for crafty kiddo
text: My 9 year old is really into crafts lately so I thought she would love this - and she did! She proceeded to make everyone in the family a little bracelet. She did not need my help in creating them which helped with my sanity. I lowered the rating by one star as the price is a bit high for what is included in the box.

title: Perfect set for siblings that fight over EVERYTHING
text: My 9 and 5 year old seem to fight over just about everything lately - including fidgets. I really liked this set because there were multiples of the fidgets which meant my kids could each have one which decreased (but of course did not eliminate) the fighting. Great gift option. We used them as stocking stuffers.

title: Perfect gift
text: My 9 and 5 year olds created these together. It made a really nice Christmas gift that they shared together. The only negative is that they completed it quickly so it did not last long. This activity also brought me back to childhood since I used to make these as a kid too!

title: Sizing can vary.
text:
Fun Frozen-esque dresses that we used for our trip to Cinderella's Castle in WDW. They were sturdy enough to last the night, and now serve as excellent PJs.

The sizing was a bit off, however. We ordered two different sizes; the smaller size fit our youngest perfectly, and was true to size, but the larger size was looser, even though we ordered the correct size.

title: Excellent quality.
text: Excellent-quality dinosaurs that have realistic textures and appearances. Of course, this is based off Hollywood's interpretation of dinosaurs, but still fun to play with.

title: High quality.
text: Great dinosaurs for the price. They feel strong in the hand and like they'll last for years. They don't move much, but there's enough movement to keep the kid's imagination rolling.

title: Excellent first crokinole board.
text:
I heard so many great things about this game, but never had an opportunity until ordering this board. The game seems like a blast, and very easy to learn. After acquiring this board, I learned that it's even easier to learn, and fun for many ages.

The board is fine for the price. I didn't expect it to be made of high-quality wood, but for the price the board is fine enough. The discs that come with the board slide smoothly across the surface; the disc themselves are perfectly uniform.

Thus far, we've been playing before the board has been oiled. Out of the box, the board is smooth enough for easy gameplay. My youngest daughter, 5 years old, picked up the game almost immediately. It's already one of our favorites.

title: A nice upgrade, but needs a copule fixes.
text:
We have the non-electronic version that costs far less. We found that one to be fun, but the cards are difficult to read in the center dome. We opted for this electronic upgrade.

With this, the board is fully plastic, replicated after the film version. The front isn't colored, though; instead, everything is the same brown color. The game can be difficult to open at times; my kids usually need parental help with prying the two doors open.

Everything mostly is the same from the non-electronic version; the cards and pieces are identical. Of course, the main upcharge here is the electronic dome. Rather than having to place extra cards into the dome to read the riddles, players just press the dome to have a riddle displayed. Oddly, the riddles can be difficult to read still. In the non-electronic version, the riddles on the cards are encrypted by random colors; it's not until the card is placed under the dome that they become decrypted. In the electronic version, the player has to be directly above the dome in order to read what is displayed. Because of the angle of the dome and the electronic screen inside, it's difficult to read what's displayed if looking at the dome from an angle.

One major complaint we all have is how loud the effects are. At times, we have to close our ears because the speaker is both too loud and not made well (there is "tinny" feedback). I checked all around the game but couldn't find a way to lower the volume.

Another complaint is that the pieces don't fit well when putting the game away. There is no compartment to tuck everything neatly. The doors of the game close too tight against the bottom that there's hardly any wiggle room for the pieces to be put away. We have everything in a couple sandwich bags, but the timer has to be disassembled every time if we want everything to fit.

It's a nice upgrade from the non-electronic version, but, with the current issues previously addressed, I don't think it warrants its MSRP.

title: Fun, colorful bath toys
text: B toys makes fun and durable toys for kids and these bath toys are just that - fun and durable! My youngest enjoys playing with them when talking baths. I really love the packaging as well - it would make for a great gift.

title: Cute!
text:
Polly Pocket has come a long way. I had Mighty Max sets when I was a kid, and my sister had Polly Pocket. Both were durable and made of hard plastic.
I wasn't aware Polly Pocket was back (or has been popular), and was thrilled to get this set for my daughter. It's a great way to take a complete play set on the go; I played with my MM sets at home, in the car, and when visiting family. My daughters do the same now with their Polly Pocket sets (we have a few now!).

This one comes with two figures that are made of a softer plastic, almost rubbery in nature. The details are far better than in decades past, and the play set contains many features that, while technically two-dimensional, add loads of depth and fun.

title: Love the different shape options!
text: My daughter has another set of these and she loves this set just as much! I love that this set comes with a wide range of shapes to appease everyone. My daughter likes taking these to camp with her to show her friends. It's a great activity for long car rides. My daughter also has ADHD and these help her focus. I never would've thought these would be as entertaining as they are! Definitely recommend.

title: Quality of the pieces is great. Board could be improved.
text:
The pieces themselves are lovely. They feel solid and are pleasant to hold in the hand. They appear smooth but have a slight grainy texture which improves grip.
The board is fine, but can be improved. There is no lock to keep the board flat, and when it is flat there is still some unevenness when the two halves meet.

title: These pack a punch!
text: Fantastic dodgeballs that are both easy to grab and easy to throw. They retain their shape despite being kept outdoor (though I strongly suggest keeping them indoor) and definitely let the victim know when they're out.

title: Fun toys. No mold.
text: Fun toys that do change color and get a hoot out of my 4-year-old. The plastic surfacing is a bit of the brittle side, but thus far drops onto the bathtub haven't created even a dent.

title: Lovely.
text: Lovely decals that are easily to place and (mostly) easy to remove. They use a great adhesive that doesn't leave residue on the window. When they're tricky to remove, a sharp fingernail usually does the trick.
