title: Bright, colorful, but screen-printing's a bit substandard.
text:
The animals are fun, playful, and made of hard plastic (not the good kind from a handful of years ago, but a smooth, hard plastic). They're made well to be tossed and loved.
The printing on the human isn't the best. It looks like cheap t-shirt silk-screening, but does the job.

title: Amazing set.
text:
I've wanted to learn to play this game for years, and I am so thrilled finally to be able to. Initially, I had graduated from college, landed my first job, and bought games to play with others. I wanted go and mahjong sets, but didn't think there would be anyone to play with. Fast-forward about twelve years and now I am in my own home with a daughter who's old enough to learn.

Upon ordering this set, I researched advice for beginners. Some argued that the stones ought to be oiled first. I got some stone-safe oil and a few drops of essential oil and oiled the stones. The stones felt great before oiling, but they felt better after. The board and bowls I oiled with mineral oil.
When everything dried, I read the included Way to Go booklet, and watched a few videos. My daughter and I play our first game; we both had fun, and I was glad to hear she wanted to play more games.

For now, we're starting with the easier side, but I like that there's a complex side. The included felt case is fine, but it's a bit too snug for the board. I foresee it ripping after a few games.

title: A blast for about a few minutes.
text: The materials are great and I believe it's worth the price. However, the actual game isn't much fun. Every time we play, if everyone doesn't start at the same time, the person beginning has the advantage because the ball is difficult to deflect. Perhaps if the playing board weren't angled then it would be more challenged.

title: A wonder!
text:
MUCH improved in the last few years. My sister received an older model one Christmas in the '90s. My oldest daughter received one a handful of years ago. And now my youngest daughter receives the latest iteration.
From just the version my oldest daughter received, there are many improvements. First, this one can fold; this makes it so that it's bigger than the one my oldest daughter had, but can be folded and will stay in place for better storage. There's even a handle on top for easier toting.
The silo actually has particles within (that can't get out, thankfully)--makes for more fun! The electronics on this thing are clear and loud, but not too loud. There really has been a lot of thought and design put into this farm. Hands down, this is the best farm I've witnessed yet.

title: Easy to build.
text:
This replaced a previous Step2 kitchen we had. The only thing missing with this one is a microwave. Otherwise, everything else is there.

I like that there are screws to be used, but they dig into the actual plastic. The oven is VERY difficult to open and close. Even I, a grown man, have difficulty opening and closing it at times. My girls just leave it slightly open.

Once built, however, it looks great. I really like the modern look of this one; the look itself is a substantial upgrade from the previous model we had.

title: Daughter loves it!
text:
Our youngest is REALLY into Little People, and loves the animals. Little People has come a long way since I was a child; while I'm not a fan of the material used for the figures (the plastic used from about 5-10 years ago was better), the sculptures of the figures are great, and each retain that Little People feel.

The train is an awesome addition to the collection. The train plays sounds and words, and easy accomodates other animals.

title: Lovely!
text: Wonderful addition to the Little People collection. The baby fits well in the high chair, and the accessories go smoothly with other Little People figures.

title: Lovely.
text: Youngest loves the set. The crib is a bit large compared to other Little People accessories of the same form.

title: A blast
text: Little People have come a long way over the years, yet they continue to be a child favorite. My youngest is obsessed with Little People toys. This one is fantastic. The plastic is thick and durable, which will help it withstand years of "love." The animals are fun, but I wish there were more.

title: Daughter loves this version!
text: This is our first set of international draughts (checkers). I never played the 10x10 version, and I greatly appreciate the complexity it adds. My oldest learned checkers playing with this set, and she asks to play frequently. The board and pieces seem to be made of good quality. The wood came a bit dry, so I oiled the board and pieces using mineral oil. The pieces slide much better now (though very slippery at first). There are no felt bottoms on the draught pieces, though I imagine that's for creating kings more easily. Because the board folds, there is a slight unevenness to it when flat. It extends through only two squares, but it's there.

title: Fun game!
text:
My eight-year-old daughter loves this game, and it's one of our go-to's so far this holiday season. It's a very fun and easy game. However, the box it comes in opens very easily, so half the time we grab it the dominoes want to fall out. Be sure to keep a rubber band or something to keep the box closed and prevent the dominoes from falling out.
The material is also pretty thin, and the color bars on the dominoes are just stickers. Pretty good stickers, but still stickers.

title: Fast, but fragile.
text: Definitely one of the fastest and smoothest cubes I've used, but the plastic is very light and fragile. One drop and the pieces go flying.

title: Cute, but small.
text: VERY small piggy bank. Because the top half is all electronics, only the clear half is the actual currency storage.

title: Pig is fine. Electronics are good.
text: The electronics are decent in this bag. The pig is made of clear plastic, which is what we wanted for our 4-year-old.

title: Fun, if a bit clunky.
text:
I'm not the best at this game. I attend annual retro-game cons and have a group of friends with whom I play this game on an original IBM. It's fun on there, but handheld is a different experience.
The buttons don't have a very satisfying feel to them; they're not the snappy buttons you can find on dedicated controllers, but they do the job. The arrows are a bit odd, especially when it comes to hunting. I have a hard time aiming, and I'm terrible as it is at hunting. But for the rest of the game, this works great, and the screen is decent enough for the price. Great little novelty item.

title: Difficult to get this to work.
text: When it works, it's fun. But it works only about 20% of the time. You need to pull a string that winds around the device, and have the internal constantly moving by moving your arm. But getting it to stay spinning from the moment you pull the string to moving your arm is a chore in itself. It hardly stays at a good speed, so it doesn't give me the workout it's supposed to.

title: Nice to supplement the Magna-Tiles.
text: These aren't as sturdy as the name-brand Magna-Tiles, but they're far cheaper and provide good supplementation to our sets. We can not build larger structures even if the colors don't exactly match.

title: Immense fun.
text: My daughters and I love playing with this. The materials will last a while and the playset allows for different characters from the Imaginext line to play. While it's not a complex Batcave by any means, it still gives children a good idea of how the batcave is carved.

title: Fun but simple.
text: Pretty cool setup, but there's not much to do unless you have more tracks.

title: A couple of tweaks to make it better.
text:
It works almost like the ones in the arcade, but there's room for improvement. My child popped a puck in and it got stuck on top of one of the needles; we shook it to let it loose.
Also, there needs to be a cover over the main board. Right now there is no cover and I'm afraid the needles could get damaged because they're exposed. Also, I wish the slots were dry-erase rather than paper. I'm sure the company did this so they could keep selling the slot papers, but it would've been nice to make it dry-erase instead.

Otherwise, it's fun and our family uses it for summer homework activities.

title: Such a fun activity that also targets fine motor skills!
text:
I really love this marble run for a variety of reasons - some of which include:
1. Hours of fun for my kids so they don't bug me while I'm working
2. Works on my kids fine motor skills by requiring them to place the pieces together
3. Requires the kids to work together and take turns by putting the pieces together one at a time
4. Allows them to work on teamwork by combing their vision for what the tower is going to look like.

I would highly recommend this - great gift idea too!

title: Simple Frozen-Themed Toy
text: This Fischer Price Frozen-themed toy will be loved by any young Elsa/Anna admirer. My 4 year old daughter was excited to play with this toy upon receiving it; she has really only take Anna and Elsa and brought them to her other toys. The "winter wonderland" itself doesn't have much for kids to do; it is a very basic toy. There is a swing and little ice skating rink, but that's it. My 4 year old played with the actual set for about two minutes before just taking Anna/Elsa to her other toys. I would keep this in mind when purchasing. The toy itself is durable and what you would expect from Fischer Price/Little People.

title: Perfect gift! Brings me back to childhood
text: Who doesn't remember Polly Pockets as a kid?! What nostalgia! My daughter opened this and has been playing with it ever since (she even slept with it next to her the first few nights!). This particular set is easily transportable in that it comes with a strap so you can carry it from one place to another. This is perfect for keeping kids occupied on long car rides or road trips. This set is a sea theme and comes with two dolls. This would be a perfect gift!

title: Lots of fun!
text: Really fun, oversized playset that can expand with your figure collection, and be easily put away. It's a nice little BB-8 that fits in both our toy chest and toy basket. It's been tossed around and only some paint has come off. I will say that the electronics are VERY sensitive. Every time we inadvertently move it we hear BB-8 go off.

title: Adorable superhero set!
text: This superhero set is adorable! It is perfect for the little superhero fanatic. We have an 8 year old and 3 year old and our youngest wants to be just like her sister, who is obsessed with superheroes! This set gives her the opportunity to play with similar toys as her sister. I love that they included both boy and girl superheroes in this set. Extremely durable; great gift for any toddler/preschooler.

title: Phenomenal.
text:
I can't believe this set exists. It's based on an imagined set that was shown briefly, but of course people like me would obsess over. Building it was sublime. The included minifigures were a worthy addition to my collection. The brick-per-cent ratio was decent, but keep in mind the license. You always pay a little extra for licensed products.
Great experience either solo (no pun intended) or with family or friends.

title: Fun way to teach kids how to tell time
text: This is a great, creative way to teach kids how to tell time. It has two settings - one with music and one with questions. My daughter prefers the music setting. The clock does have a feature where you can use it as an indicator for when a child should wake up, but I haven't used this feature. We are only using it as a means to teach our daughter how to tell time. Highly recommend.

title: Cute MealTime Play Set; Not very durable
text: We absolutely LOVE Melissa and Doug products - they are fun, colorful, and creative. This set is no exception. It comes with meal-time pieces for any baby doll. The only drawback is the cardboard pieces were not durable and did not last long in our house. If you want a toy that will last, I would recommend looking at Melissa and Doug's other products - the cardboard just didn't work for us.

title: Perfect LEGO set!
text: My daughter is obsessed with LEGOS and she absolutely loved putting this LEGO set together. This set comes with a horse barn including a tractor, one figure, two horses, and a fenced in area for the horses. This would be great to add onto other LEGO sets for imaginative play. Highly recommend as a gift for any LEGO fan.

title: Perfect gift for a LEGO fan!
text: We absolutely love LEGO sets in our house and this set did not disappoint! My oldest daughter loved working on this with her dad. It is extremely detailed - includes a three level fire station with a garage. It also includes four figurines which is great for imaginative play; my daughter and her friends have a blast with it. We keep it on a shelf in the playroom so she can play with it whenever she wants. Highly recommend as a gift as well.

title: Durable; high quality
text: These scissors are extremely durable and high quality. They are comfortable to hold, especially when doing a significant amount of cutting. I would highly recommend these scissors.

title: My daughter loves it
text: For some reason, my 7 year old daughter LOVES the Pikmi Pop toys. She loves the way they feel and can't wait to smell them when opening them. I honestly do not see the appeal. The smell can be a bit overpowering for me. If you don't mind dealing with the smell that comes along with these toys, they will make your child very happy.

title: Brings me back to childhood
text: This set brings me right back to my childhood in the 90s playing with Polly Pockets! This Shopkins set is perfect for any young child. My daughters love Shopkins and enjoyed playing with this mini playset. They really enjoyed figuring out the code to unlock the playset. This would make a great gift for any Shopkins fan.

title: Fun Sequin Flip Pillow!
text: The sequin flip pillows are extremely popular right now! This pillow is fun, colorful, and perfect for a little one that loves to flip sequins! It is comfy and adds a sparkle to my daughter's bedroom decor. I would recommend this for any young child that loves sequin pillows.

title: Great bath toy!
text: My toddler loves this bath toy. She's had it for a while and it's very durable. It is easily washable so it doesn't get moldy like some bath toys do. Highly recommend!

title: My kids are obsessed with BABY SHARK
text: This was a great toy for our youngest daughter. She is obsessed with the baby shark songs and she loved seeing this shark dance and sing! This would make a great gift for a Baby Shark fanatic.

title: Great gift for the little artist in your life; keeps kids occupied at home
text: My oldest daughter LOVES art and she has really enjoyed using these as part of her daily art projects especially since being stuck at home during the quarantine. My daughter has loved the variety of colors in this set! Great addition to a child's art collection

title: Great for 4-6 year olds; love B-Toys!
text: Our family just loves the toys from B-Toys!! This suction paddle game was difficult for my three year old daughter to use. Even though the product information states that it is for toddlers, I would argue that it would be better for 4-6 year olds. My 3 year old really struggled to get the ball to suction to the paddle. It wasn't worth the tantrums and frustration for her.

title: Great quarantine activity!
text: This is a great activity when stuck at home! We absolutely love all things Melissa and Doug and this toy wasn't any different. It allowed my second grader to express her creativity in a new way and kept her occupied. She was fairly independent in peeling off the stickers and spreading the glue on top. I would definitely recommend this as a gift for a child that loves art projects!

title: Great creative activity for children
text:
My 7 year old daughter is extremely creative and loves to express herself in different ways. She enjoyed using the playfoam to make different figurines. The only drawback to this toy is that I don't see it as a good gift (not all parents want their kids to have foam) and it was really just a one time use and then my daughter was over it.

This would be perfect for the current quarantine going on! Something to keep the kids busy.

title: Lovely tune.
text: The speakers are fantastic in this thing. A year's worth of playing, and the toy still charms crystal-clear. My 3yo loves it, even though she may be a bit big for it by now.

title: Comparable to other dolls
text: This doll is comparable to the dolls at Target and the American Girl dolls. It's durable and comes with a stylish outfit. We gave this to my six year old daughter and she loves it. Definitely recommend as a great gift idea.

title: Difficult to control at first, but fun to use.
text:
This is the first drone that I've used that's meant for indoor play. I have two kids but I opened this while they were in bed so I could get a chance to play with it first!

After charging it up, I read the basic instructions to get a feel for the controls. As I mentioned, I've never used a drone before (let alone indoors), so I wasn't sure what to expect. I do have an indoor helicopter that I purchased about a decade ago (the one that was all the rage on Amazon during that time), so that's been my only indoor air-R/C experience. This thing moves fast! It's very difficult to control at first because the directional inputs register very quickly, causing the drone to smack into objects. Going up and down isn't as fast as going in cardinal directions, so you have to get a feel for its positioning before registering a direction.

About a week after I finally got them down. I like that it comes with extras in case you need to repair it. For the cost, it's a great entry-level drone.

title: Great starter kit.
text:
Great kit to start with, and doesn't take very long to build. I build Gunpla and other Japan-based kits, and this one took me about half an hour from opening the package to completion.
Plays great.

title: Great addition to play kitchen
text: This is a great addition to my daughter's play kitchen! These are extremely high quality and are durable. It comes with a potholder and oven mitt which my daughter loves! I really like the stand that holds all of the toys. It's perfect for storage. Definitely recommend this as a gift for the little baker in your life!

title: Great set of sand toys
text: This set comes with a wagon, bucket, and variety of sand toys. The wagon is a nice touch. My oldest (6) can pull it around the park and beach with no problem. It also holds the bucket and sand toys. The wagon and toys have been extremely durable. I've used BToys products in the past and have never been disappointed.

title: Strong and durable. Perfect for the park or beach
text: This set is recommended for children over the age of 18 months. My two girls (2,6) really enjoyed playing with these at the beach and park last summer. They're extremely durable and are made with fun, bright colors! I love that the pieces can be transported easily in the bucket.

title: So much fun!
text: This is a durable, fun toy that is perfect for children over the age of three. My daughter was very excited to transform this toy truck! I would definitely purchase another Super Wings toy afternoon our experience with this one. This would also make a great gift idea!

title: Tough to clean but kids loved it
text: My youngest daughter (2.5) loved playing with in the tub! She loves to color so the fact she could use crayons in the tub got her extremely excited. When she was finished using it, I had a heck of a time removing the crayon from the whale and the tub. Unfortunately, due to this we won't be using this for bath time again. I don't have the time to be scrubbing crayon off the tub :-/

title: Good learning toy. Simple plastics.
text:
Got these for my two-year-old. She's able to match up the shapes easily enough, but I'm not sure if it's more color-matching than shape-matching. The base of each cup fits into each saucer only certain ways because they have different shapes each, but they all correspond with appropriate colors. Not sure if you needed the different colors; if the shapes were a priority, solid colors probably would've been a better choice.
But my daughter loves the set well enough and uses it with her other kitchen toys. There's really nothing else to this set other than what you see. No electronics or anything else. The teacups barely fit in the pot, but with some maneuvering they fit.

title: Daughters love it. Very "real," but can get annoying.
text:
My two-year-old loves the doll. It's a pretty potty-training doll in that it can absorb liquids and does a good job of showing children when to and how ot use the potty. It even makes gas noises, which at first took me aback but then made me realize it's natural to show children about bowel movements. After all, this is a potty-training doll!

Sometimes the doll activates on its own, and it's then that I find it kind of annoying. The doll usually resides in the bed or in the toy trunk, and I can hear it activate.
So far, so good, though. The liquids pass through just fine, even after months of having this doll.

title: They need to revive this line.
text: These are easily my favorite Ninja Turtle toys ever. I used to have the NECA comic-style turtles, and I'm fully aware of the Figuarts versions as well as the First Gokin enemies, but these are still my favorite. MEGA made so many versions of these characters and they're fun to set up and display. The articulation is great for this line. My Donatello has a loose neck joint, but otherwise it's great. The paint application is so-so.

title: Great fun for little ones
text: My kids loved playing with this train set. This is the first Thomas toy we've owned so it was great watching my kids as they navigates the wooden train track. I would definitely recommend this toy for any train or Thomas lover.

title: Lots of fun! Great gift idea
text:
Play-doh has always been a huge hit with my kids! My six year old daughter loves to help me bake in the kitchen so when given a play doh set to make her own cupcakes- she was so excited! I would recommend this playdoh set for 4 years and older given the materials and what needs to be done to create the cupcakes.
This would be a great gift idea for the preschooler on your list!

title: Fun way to get into the game.
text: The cards here are all you need to get started in the game. You don't get any figures with it, but as these combine with teh figures to make a "life-like" experience, the goal here is to focus on the tabletop experience. The base cards are included and, of course, you can always expand. Decent accessories are included as well, such as a paper mat (though I prefer to use my Khalsa Brain mat) and, of course, the inevitable booster pack. Expect to buy more, as well as the figures!

title: Cannot recommend. Such a frustration.
text:
What I thought would be a fun holiday toy for my kids turned out to be a huge pain and battery guzzler. While packaged nicely, it was evident that you get a product that, in my opinion, isn't even worth the relatively low price point. The controller is made of thin plastic and has unnecessary triggers that make me wonder whether it's a generic mold that's been used for game controllers of some sort.
The body of the car is a bit sturdier, at least. With the fat tires, the body hardly ever touches surfaces.

When I first took the parts out of the box the first thing I did was open up the back of the controller to put in batteries. The battery cover also has a screw to keep it in place, but I soon realized that the plastic screw (or else very cheap metal) was broken so that no matter how much I turned it it would not loosen. I didn't strip the top; the screw itself was broken. Thus, I had to bend and crack the battery cover open to get the batteries in. "Okay," I thought. "At least that'll probably be the worst of it."
Nope.

I did the same for the car. Thankfully, that screw wasn't broken so it came off without any manipulation. The instructions state that a rechargeable battery is inside, but that's not the case. Instead, there's a compartment that requires four AAA batteries. I stock up on plenty of AA batteries, but as AAA batteries are becoming less common I had to order some. Not a big deal; I've been meaning to stock up on some anyway. And I actually prefer batteries over internal rechargeable ones as that means better longevity. (I have this twenty-year-old RC car that is useless now because the rechargeable battery is impossible to find a replacement for.)

So I got the batteries all set and I started to play with it. As it was late at night my kids were asleep, so I figured what better way to test it before they had a chance!
The car moved fine. It detected all my presses. However, two big problems I noticed were: 1) to push the car forward, you have to push both triggers forward (or backward if the car's on its flip side), but every time I did the car would make a slight turn left before continuing forward. I tried countless times to see if it was me but it would not go straight before turning a slight left.
2) Because the underside of the car is mirrored from the top I sometimes forget that I'm supposed to reverse the controls. I wish they made the mold of the car so that they wouldn't be facing the same direction.

Anyway, I figured my kids would have fun with it and wouldn't bother with these gripes. They woke up and noticed the car immediately on the table, and I let them have at it. For a while, they had a lot of fun, but not too long did they complain that the car wouldn't go straight. When the car would stop and they'd try to get it to go just straight, sure enough it would turn slightly left before going straight. Despite their complaints, however, they used it the entire day.
By the end of the day, the batteries inside the car already needed replacing. Mind you, they didn't use it every second of the day, but I was still surprised to find that the batteries needed replacing already. I changed them and thought nothing of it.

Two days later was Thanksgiving and my kids wanted to bring it while visiting family. When we got there the car needed battery replacements yet again. In those two days prior to the holiday they used it probably a max of about half an hour. There's a switch on the car that turns it off and on, but then I realized that if it's not turned off then the batteries still are being drained. I thought we'd be fine to leave the car switched on and the batteries would be in a sort of idle state, but that was not the case. As the family we visited didn't have AAA batteries, my kids weren't able to use it. It wasn't a total loss as we had plenty of other activities to do, but even I was looking forward to using the car with a couple of pets brought by family.

So when we got back home I replaced the batteries. When my kids went to bed I remembered to turn the car off. The next day they played with it and forgot to turn it off that night. The next day it needed replacements again. I told my kids I'm not replacing the batteries again and then I showed them this RC helicopter I had. They've forgotten about the car.

title: Fun!
text:
Great, fun little turtle. Colorful, which is a combination of the 80s cartoon and advertising. The colors in the original cartoon aren't as vibrant, but after the show took off the TMNT took on more vibrant tones in product merchandising; it's the latter that these "Classic" turtles look like.
Has lots of articulation and comes with his standard weapons. Unfortunately, there's no way to store them when not in hand, so that's the only reason it lacks 5 stars.

title: Great for kids, but may need adult help.
text:
My two-year-old and I built this together.
Okay, I mostly built it, but she stayed put as I built it, watching eagerly as it all came together. In total it took me a few minutes as both the set is simple as well as the instructions were simple. There are no stickers (or at least we didn't spot any; I'm sure my two-year-old would've noticed them), and the boat is overall nice. Few pieces, and great for two-year-olds wiht adult assistance.

title: Great rug for a playroom
text: This is the perfect rug for a playroom or kids room. It measures 58x79 and has a backing that prevents sliding. It has letters, numbers, and shapes on the rug which is perfect for little ones. This rug also comes with a pack of cards. My daughter used the cards to match to each item on the rug (see attached picture). My girls are extremely excited to have this in their playroom!

title: Cute unicorn with sequins!!!
text:
My daughter absolutely loved this stuffed unicorn. She's been recently obsessed with sequins. I've bought her several T-shirt's with sequins and she loves to flip it back and forth. It seems to calm her.
This stuffed unicorn with sequins was perfect for her because she could flip the sequins while in bed and before falling asleep. The sequins turn from silver to multi-colored. It's also weighted. My daughter doesn't have sensory issues, but this could help Kids with sensory issues too.

I will definitely be buying these for my daughter's friends as their birthday parties come up!

title: Love this wagon!
text:
This is a great wagon to use to transport the kids or hold a bunch of stuff! It took my husband and I about 20 minutes to assemble it and it folds up nicely (as shown in picture). It holds about 150 pounds and was perfect for my six and two year olds when we went trick or treating. The wagon comes with two seats inside. The seats can be folded to the side of the wagon, allowing more space for storage. It is easy to pull along sidewalk.
Can't wait to use it with the canopy come summer!

title: Great set of blocks
text:
This set consists of 35 blocks that are made of a cork material that is lightweight and eco-friendly. The blocks are made for children 3 and up. My daughters (ages 6 and 2) loved playing with these blocks. I have a few pros and cons:

Pros:
1. The main thing that I loved about them is how quiet they are! My kids love to dump out blocks which was perfectly fine with these because they didn't make the loud noise – which I'm sure our neighbors appreciate given we are on the third floor.
2. These are so versatile and light weight – they'd be perfect for home, classrooms, daycares, etc. This means little kids won't have trouble picking them up/cleaning them up and they won't do a lot of damage if thrown on the floor either.

Cons:
1. My 2-year-old attempted to place the items in her mouth several times, which explains why the recommended age is 3 and up. I would even recommend for ages 4 and up at a minimum given the possibility of biting on the cork or the cork falling apart.
2. Only two sizes in the set I received. This means I would have to buy an additional set for a variety of shapes/sizes.

title: Great playset for young kids
text:
I grew up with American Girl dolls so to see this building set with the American Girl theme, it was like being sent back to my childhood!

This set is designed for children ages 8-12 years old. I would agree with this age range. My 6 year old daughter is building it and it seems a bit difficult for her. It has been, however, a great project for her and me to do together! She enjoys building things and inherited my American Girl dolls so this has been the perfect toy for her.

The title wasn't kidding when they said ‘Mega'! It is a HUGE set and takes a while to set up. It consists of a Victorian style house (Samantha's house from the American Girl collection). This house is three stories and contains six rooms. My daughter has worked on it a couple hours total and has a whole lot more to build!

This would be a great gift for any child interested in building and/or American Girls. There is so much attention to detail with the pieces. I've attached pictures of the items my daughter has created from the kit so far.

title: Perfect for little hands
text:
My daughter is two years old and is obsessed with babies - not just any babies but babies with hats. This little baby doll is no different. She carries this baby around everywhere. She loves the bottle that came along with the baby. She attempts to feed the baby, but also places the bottle in her own mouth. This is the perfect first doll for any little boy or girl. I love the soft fabric of the doll's body - any even bigger plus that it's washable!

The only drawback to this doll is that the hat is not attached to the baby is anyway. My daughter NEEDS to have the hat on the baby at all times and becomes upset each time that it falls off. For our family, not having the hat attached to the baby is an inconvenience because heaven forbid we lose the hat - MELTDOWN CITY! For others, I know that being able to remove the hat is a plus.

Overall, my daughter LOVES this doll! Our family will look into purchasing this doll for friends and family members with little ones.

title: Fun toy that is easy to transport
text: I picked this out for my six year old daughter. She gets bored easily in the car and this seemed like the perfect solution. It transports easily, making it great for car trips or trips to grandpa's house. I liked how there are a variety of puzzles and that you can gradually increase the difficulty of the puzzles. My daughter gets easily frustrated so being able to gradually increase the difficulty decreased her frustration level. This is a great, fun, educational activity kids can do by themselves or with you!

title: Cute set of board books - great gift idea
text:
This is a cute set of four board books about trucks. I gave this to my two year old daughter who loved looking through the pages. They are currently withstanding the love (mouthing, ripping, etc) that my two year old gives them! They are great for girls and boys. They are easy for my two year old to hold herself. They also contain information about each of the vehicles so it is also educational! These are also small enough where they can fit in the diaper bag or in my purse to keep her busy when out and about.
One drawback of these books is the price - I think $18 is a bit steep for four small board books, but this high price tag might be taking into account the gift box that these four books come in.

title: We love B Toys!
text: I absolutely love the B Toys brand. We have several of their other toys and they have stood the test of time, loved by both of my kids (six years old, two years old). This toy is no different. My two year old loves this toy! She is obsessed with our neighbor's cat, so she favors the little black cat in this kit. She has difficulty with the keys and placing in the holes, but that is just because she hasn't developed the fine motor skills to be able to do that yet. She enjoys listening to the cat's heartbeat and checking her temperature. Although my two year old plays with this set most often, my six year old has also played with it on occasion. I would recommend this toy for children between the ages of 2-5.

title: Not very sturdy
text: I was slightly disappointed with the product when it arrived as it was not what I expected it to be. It isn't very sturdy and the mirrors on the front are not even mirrors at all. My daughter is six years old and she plays with this when playing with her dolls, but it is not holding up well to the wear and tear of two young kids (six year old, two year old). I would much rather have an armoire that will last a while. The upside is that assembly is easy and the armoire comes with two little baskets inside for additional storage.

title: Great game for the whole family
text: This is a great game to play as a family - whether indoors or outdoors on the deck! It has checkers on one side and 4 in a row on the other. Both of these games are simple and great for my young kids to play with us. It's durable so I expect to have this for a while.

title: Endless fun!
text: LOVE these bristle blocks! The product packaging states for children 24 months-8 years, but this can be fun for all ages! Such a great activity to do with my two young kids. My daughter loves to use this to build cars and towns. This would be a great birthday gift for a boy or a girl. I absolutely love that the blocks fit inside the container for easy storage. The price is also extremely reasonable ($18.55). Can't be beat!

title: Very realistic doll
text: This is a cute doll that my almost 6-year-old daughter just loves to play with. I find that this doll is comparable to the dolls found at Target (My Generation). They're also similar to the American Girl Dolls I had as a kid. The doll looks very realistic and comes with a very cute outfit that is interchangeable. Her eyes open and close. Her head and limbs move and the doll has a soft body, making her seem even more realistic. This is a doll my daughter can grow up with.

title: Great toy for little ones just learning to talk
text: I'm usually annoyed by kids toys that make a lot of noise. They never seem to stop making noise! My 18 month old, however, just LOVES this toy. She loves stacking the blocks and listening to the songs. This toy exposes her to new words, phrases, colors, and numbers. She's learning as she is playing! My daughter is also obsessed with animals - especially puppies and kitties - so she is in love with the puppy on this toy. What worries me a bit is, what happens if we lose the blocks? Honestly, we lose a ton of toys every day. Without the blocks, it's not as interactive. That's not that big of a deal though given all of it's other features. Definitely a great toy for little ones just learning to talk!

title: Kids liked it but it's a pain to put together and take apart
text:
This train set is recommended for kids 24 months-5 years. We have an 18 month old and almost 6 year old at home. They both had a blast with this train set once it was set up. Setting it up, however, was quite the chore! It was extremely hard to put together for us parents, let alone the kiddos. It is also difficult to disassemble. Luckily, it comes with a little bag to store all of the pieces which is convenient.
If you're looking for a toy that your kid can put together by themselves, this isn't it. You will have to assist them with putting it together and taking it apart. It is also quite expensive for a kids toy (in my opinion), especially for one that needs so much assistance.

title: Fun activity for older kiddos
text:
My daughter loves jewelry and creating things so I thought this would be a nice addition to her toys. This is definitely something that kids need to do with an adult. It can't be done independently. It was very frustrating for my daughter (who is only six) to wait for the water to heat and wait for the crystals to form. After a while, she just gave up. I would definitely recommend this kit for kiddos closer to the minimum age stated on the box (age eight).
For the price and what you get, it's a great buy and something fun to do over a weekend.

title: Great bath toys, but a pain to put back together.
text:
These are definitely some of the nicest bath toys we've had. The presentation itself is really nice: they come in a nice box and positioned in ways that show you which animal goest paired with which bath float.
Opening the box, you're hit with a powerful chemical smell, but after a couple of baths that goes away.

My daughters love the toys and are always fighting over who gets to play with which. However, we've learned not to pop the heads off as often to clean them. It's fun to swap bodies on the three quadrupeds (the bird's sections are compatible with the others), but it's such a pain to put them back together that we've resorted to leaving them alone and taking them apart only to clean.
The rubber floats cannot be disassembled, however, and so those will build up mold more quickly.

The designs themselves are very nice and colorful. Filling them up with water is quick, but they don't really squirt straight. They squirt in an arc, so it's a little trickier to aim.
Also, I feel they might be priced a bit high, though they are nice and sturdy, and definitely far better than the other bath toys we have. The floats aren't very heavy, and they don't squirt; they have a hard time keeping some of the animals on them.

title: Daughter loves it. Nice accessories.
text: This was a gift from our oldest daughter to our youngest, and the giftee was ecstatic. She's in a baby phase, and has collected a handful of baby dolls as well. She loved this one upon immediate view, and held it the rest of the day. The accessories are a nice little touch; they're all made of the same fabric (safe for the sponge) as the doll itself, which is a very soft and cuddle-able material. The hood is fold-able, so it's nice to show my daughter that it's ready for bath time.

title: Basic toy; daughters love it.
text:
The toy was played with for some time on Christmas by both my one-year-old (whose gift it was) and my five-year-old. The plastic is nice, but feels too hollow compared to something made under the Fisher-Price or Playskool names. Still, the balls fit perfectly atop before being hammered in, and they go in with little force--perfectly for the intended age.
The only thing it's missing is a dedicated spot to put the hammer when not in use.

title: Fun, but short-lasting.
text:
My one-year-old got this for Christmas and she wasn't sure what it was supposed to do. By pushing a button, you get the character to "dance," but there are only four buttons and everything is vocal, so there's really not much to understand if the owner doesn't understand to many vocal commands. After the first day it has stayed in the corner of bedroom untouched.
The toy does have a hypnotizing dance and twirl, and the lights are a nice touch to keep kids attracted to it, but there are too many vocal commands to consider it interactive.

title: Works fine.
text:
Not immune to passing fads, I acquired some fidget spinners for my daughter, and one for myself. We quickly realized that they are very easy to misplace, especially when my youngest gets a hold of one. I have one and my daughter has a few, and so we sought to get a dedicated case to house them so they won't end up strewn around the home, especially if any of the bearings happen to pop out.

The box is okay. A hard plastic, but not extremely rigid. The fit isn't perfect as the two halves take some adjustment sometimes to close. The inside a pre-cut foam that fits a handful of fidget spinners to protect them from damage. It's nothing more than your standard DIY fidget box, and honestly the huge logo on the front can be an eyesore, but it's fine for kids to hold their collection.

title: Fun toy! Hours of fun
text:
I have a five year old and a one year old daughter. They love playing with this toy!! They're able to share the various instruments inside. What I like most about it is the easy cleanup! The kids just throw the instruments inside the drum and it's all done!
B toys is an amazing brand for toys so I'm confident this set of instruments will withstand a lot of use.

title: The cards are durable and of good quality. They can be used in a variety ...
text: I'm a BCBA working with children with special needs. I'm currently using these cards to target expressive and receptive identification of animals. The cards are durable and of good quality. They can be used in a variety of ways !

title: Great toy for kids who love their dolls!
text:
My daughter LOVES this stroller!! It has everything a little girl needs to play with her dolls. My daughter can't get over that it is a stroller and a car seat and a seat to feed her dolls all in one! She plays with her dolls and imitates me when I'm with her seven month old sister.
This would be a great gift for any child who enjoys playing with their dolls!

title: Nice toy/gift for Shimmer and Shine lovers
text: My daughter absolutely loves this toy! She's obsessed with the show and the theme song. This necklace fits her perfectly (she's four years old). She's been wearing it everywhere we go. She pushes the button on the top of the genie bottle with her chin when wearing it and thinks she's hilarious. Definitely recommend this as a gift to any kid who likes the Shimmer and Shine show.

title: Great coloring set!
text:
My four year old daughter is obsessed with coloring. I've always through Crayola products were the best. This set is no exception. I agree with other reviewers in that it is MUCH bigger than expected.

Only drawback to this set is the price. It's fairly expensive considering the items you get. If you bought the items separately, you would pay less. You're paying extra for the case.

Overall, it's a great kit. It would make an awesome gift along with coloring books for the avid colorer in your life :-)

title: The only downside is that the cars don't stay connected very well.
text:
My daughter loves this, but the one flaw I'd point out firstly is that the trains don't hook on securely. Every bump over the carpet or crossing a wood threshold careens at least one of the cars away. At first I thought this was so because the company thought it would be easier for younger kids to attach them, but then I found all the little accessories and how small they were and somewhat difficult for my daughter to open, then I realized they could've done a better job of making the hooks curve more so that the cars stay attach. Hence the four instead of five stars.

Otherwise, this play set is fantastic and my daughter has been playing with them nonstop. She loves the accessories they come with, and enjoys putting them and removing them on/from the pony. It's also great because lately she's been obsessed with trains (we live near some railroads) so this combined with her recent obsession with MLP and this toy is a hit (barring the carriage hooks).

title: Like reliving my childhood.
text:
A blast from the past. I was never a LEGO kid growing up. The blocks never held much imagination in my opinion, although they do adhere to real-life architecture very well. I was gifted a huge K'Nex box one birthday and I've spent many years after that building my own creations. I love the cogs and rods better than the blocks and minifigures.
Finally, my daughter can have her own set, and I can relive that magic with her. The pieces feel like they used to when I was a kid. Sadly, I have no idea what happened to my kit, so I can't compare.
That said, we immediately started building when it arrived and have tried to create the initial sculptures I used to build as a kid. We finally went on to the other designs offered in the instructions; they're taking a little more time, but we're halfway through the Ferris wheel. My daughter is busy creating her own little creatures while I'm doing most of the work.

title: Who said it was for my kid?!
text:
As soon as I saw the picture in my Vine newsletter I had to order it. I am a product of the '90s--Power Rangers and TMNT were my childhood. As a child, however, I never had Dragonzord. When I landed my first job, however, the first things I purchased (well, besides suits) were a few Zords.
Then the Legacy line by Bandai came out years later, and it blew the original Zords away. Yes, the old ones are great for nostalgia's sake, but the Legacy ones combined metal with actual sculpted parts where stickers used to be (they even used the original Japanese designs from the show!) and they were far better than the ones made decades ago, even if they lacked electronics whatnots.
Now comes the Fisher-Price Imaginext line for toddlers. I've heard great things about Imaginext, and I couldn't wait for my daughter to get her own Dragonzord.

The toy comes in an open-style box so you can fondle the Zord in all its glory without taking it out. I was pleased right away; just like the Legacy line, everything (mostly) is sculpted, and uses the original Japanese designs. No more stickers.
It also comes with a little Imaginext Green Ranger that fits into the chest piece, as well as a handful of missiles that shoot from the chest (inaccurate as the missiles shot from the fingers whereas electricity (?) shot from the chest--but I digress).
The crowning piece is that, since this is remote-controlled, the remote comes in the style of the Dragon Dagger. Fan-flippin'-tastic.

The range is great, although admittedly we haven't used the R/C much; you will need batteries for the remote, but the Zord comes with them installed. There is a base that attaches from leg to leg that acts as the motor, and the Zord walks great and sounds great. You even get to shoot the missiles from the chest from a distance, so that's cool when we prop up Elsa against a box and blast her to smithereens (or at least until she tips over on the floor).

All in all, both dad and daughter are pleased. Mom rolls her eyes (she never was into Power Rangers) when we shoot things or crunch smaller toys in the jaws. I even love how the hands are curled like in the original show. The Legacy edition comes with these hands as well, and those are the ones I use when displayed.

title: From generation to generation.
text:
Almost every child growing up in the 80s and 90s had one, or knew someone who did. I was in both camps, and now I'm glad that we have yet another in our household.
The quality is still great for a product having been made for decades. Of course, the look and technology behind it is different, but it's still the same ol' Fisher-Price toddler's basketball set.

For starters, it takes up quite a bit of real estate if you have a small space, although that may be because the hoop is slow close the floor that it only seems that way. Living in a third-floor apartment, however, limits our basketball training, but we're still able to have a blast with it playing one-on-one.

title: One of the daughter's favorite toys.
text:
I personally never knew about these growing up, if they existed, but once I had my firstborn I've been seeing these more and more in toy stores (or maybe I've just been browsing toy stores more and more altogether). Initially I deemed them too much money for what they were and how many pieces came in a set. They're thin pieces of plastic with weak magnets. I'd imagine they should be a third of the price, but I'm no marketer.

That said, after having received a set for her birthday, my daughter plays with this very frequently, even a year later. When friends and family come to visit, this is one of the main hitters when they play with her. Nevertheless, we were always short a few pieces, so, when the opportunity arose to receive another set, of course I seized the opportunity!
Unfortunately, this new set didn't come with the pieces we needed most (the large base ones), but it does add a ton of pieces we easily can take advantage of. The colors are much more vibrant in this set (our previous one has a darker theme), but in low lighting you won't see that stark of a contrast. Plus, kids don't really care.
The newer pieces we have here are smaller triangles, which helps a ton in making small roofs, etc. We use a cookie sheet as our base, and I advise strongly to use one every time you play. Makes the experience and capability that much better.

All in all, these are great toys, even if I think they are way, way overpriced for what you get. They're constantly in play--even when I'm not home during the day, because I'm always cleaning them up at night when I get home!

title: Fantastic remake of an old classic.
text:
I never had one of these as a child, but we're all familiar with the toy. I'm not sure how I've come to know it so well despite never owning it, but I was pleasantly surprised to see a remake of this classic toy the other day.

Our daughter is a bit old for this, but we have another child on the way that we can't wait to play this toy with. Either way, our older daughter gets a kick out of it, despite its simplicity. Perhaps that's why it became so popular: it functions without any electricity, and there's a good deal to maneuver despite how minimal it appears. The eyes on this model still blink--everything actually is the same.
The only major change is that the chassis is sleeked. No more of that clunky body, but if you still want those they should be readily available; I've seen them stocked plentiful on shelves.

title: Great for old men!
text:
The "old man" being me. I got this for my toddler daughter who has various other Little People sets. She has a chariot set that has a lot of similarities to this, and even came with blocks, so this matches perfectly with that.

Putting it together for her was a cinch. Of course, which father doesn't like seeing their daughter's faces light up when they receive a gift? (Don't worry; it's not a regular thing so we don't spoil her.)

But we had a blast playing with this set, and I tried recreating scenes from Cinderella and Beauty and the Beast. I would've loved to have a Beast figure in his cursed form, but that probably wouldn't have fit this set very well.

Overall, it's great, as are all Little People sets. We have a dedicated bin where we keep Little People and Duplo toys, and this mixes well with those.

title: Loads of fun. Updated, though muted colors confuse at first.
text:
I've had Apples to Apples Party Edition for years. It's a great go-to party game for a group no more than 10 large, and it's a great addition to anyone's gaming library.

I'm a sucker for anniversary editions, so of course I picked up the 15th Anniversary Edition of Apples to Apples when I had a chance. Heck, I didn't even know it was that old until I saw this on Amazon!

While I have the Party Edition which has *way* more cards than this, that edition is half a decade old and so some of the references show age. This anniversary edition has updated terms and phrases as of 2015, so it's a bit funnier if you're playing with younger people.
The cards from the standard edition I think are a bit easier to work with. When we played with the anniversary set some people were mixed at times when grabbing the appropriate cards, as they're both monochrome except reverted instead of the red and green cards. The tokens, however, are a much welcome addition as they make it easier to tally the scores.

If you had to get a quick pick-me-up set and don't care about reusing the same cards quickly, then this set is a great buy. It has modern terms and phrases, is very sleek in its nice black box, and makes it easier to keep track of score. But really, the most fun in playing this game is coming up with absurd card mixes!

title: Doll
text: My daughter turned two about a month ago. She is obsessed with dolls and babies. She absolutely loves this baby. It is soft and a great doll to cuddle with during naps and nighttime. I think this would be a great doll for even kids under 1 years of age.

title: Pirate ship
text: Although this is a submarine, it is not made to use in water. My daughter didn't mind though because she was just excited to have a new toy to play with. My daughter is not old enough to watch Jake and the Neverland Pirates, but she did enjoy playing with it along with her other toys. The price of $29.99 is a bit expensive for what you get with this toy.

title: Daughter loves it.
text:
Being a Turtles fan, I have to raise my daughter in the fandom and paraphernalia of the pizza-loving mutants. She already has a plush Donatello and the Nick Turtles toothpaste, and now she has an officially licensed Turtle bike.

I had one like this when I was a tyke, as I'm sure many have; mine was a GI Joe and even had a water gun attached atop the handlebars (which was the first thing to break).
This has electronics with actual Nick Turtles voices and sound effects. I know there are some toys out there that don't use the show's voices, but this one does. They're loud and crisp haven't worn out despite my daughter's constant pressing. The bike comes unassembled, naturally, but is very easy to assemble. From what I can recall, all you need is the right screwdriver and a hammer.

Despite being all plastic, the bike does have some metal parts, namely the rods for the wheels. The plastic is sturdy enough and feels like it'll stand some wear. The tires rotate smoothly, and the seat adjusts to allow for different heights. My daughter is still too short seeing as she's two and short for her age, but I push her around on the bike while she maneuvers and it's fun anyway.

Fisher-Price has always made sturdy toddler bikes in my opinion, and this is no exception. It'll suffice till she's old enough for the metal tricycles.
My only complaint is that the lid for the compartment resting between the handlebars comes off easily. My daughter was taking it off since day one and I thought that was because she likes to fiddle with things. However, when I took it from her and tried to remove it, I accidentally held on to it while shutting it and when I pulled away the lid came off without effort.

title: Great little gun to have at the side.
text:
The weather hasn't been very fair to us this summer here in Chicago, but when it does go above 80 my family and like to go out for walks. We bring sidewalk chalk usually, but the last two trips I brought my Scatter Blast.

You really can't tell how much of a punch this packs just by opening it. You have to, of course, fill it with water and blast it at someone you love. So I made sure to try it on my wife before trying it on anyone else.
I won't be trying it on my daughter after I saw what it does to my wife.

For such a little gun with such little reservoir this thing packs a hit. I was surprised to see how little I had to press the pump to get a steady stream going.
Now, I haven't owned a water gun since I was a kid, so I didn't know how far water-gun technology had advanced. My wife knew I brought it along, yet she didn't think I'd dare use it on her. But how else was I supposed to test it?

Great little gun, though they could remove that false trigger. For some reason I keep wanting to press it whenever I pump the gun.

title: Fun for the whole family. Seriously.
text:
I got this with the intention that my one-year-old eventually will use it. Of course, I couldn't wait and opened it the same day it arrived.
I have the CS-35 for my own, which I love, and I wanted to add a handgun to the arsenal.

What I didn't know was that this blaster comes with three Mega Darts, and it can't use the darts from my old blaster. A shame as I have a whole chest full of `em.

In any case, this thing is a blast to use. We went to visit my parents the other day and I brought this gun with. I thought it'd be fun to play with against my kid sister as she has a few Nerf guns of her own. Alas, I was the one being shot at.

Right when we arrived my daughter took the gun and showed it to her grandfather. My dad, being the kid-at-heart, quickly taught her how to shoot the gun at me. Every time I passed by them my daughter, with my dad helping her, would take a shot. She'd miss of course, but that didn't stop them from laughing every time they tried.

It's a fantastic gun with lots of power and range. We compared it to my kid sister's Maverick, and the Magnus has a stronger impact. You also hear the darts coming your way. It's just a shame you can't use other darts.

title: Great throwback.
text:
Fantastic rendition of the older style layout. While I've grown accustomed to the upgrades over the years, especially the miniature characters, having pawns makes handling much swifter and easier, not to mention less likely for them to topple over.

The gameplay remains intact and as fun as over. As someone who prefers Settlers and Eclipse over traditional American board games, I still enjoy a good mystery-solving like Clue, especially with family during the holidays.

title: Expensive plastic, but my daughter loves it.
text:
My daughter loves Elmo. This train set was a no-brainer, and since she's getting older she'll be able to appreciate the toy more.

The track is great and made of sturdy plastic. Of course, seeing as my daughter is one, she doesn't exactly keep Elmo or Grover on the tracks.
The music is great, and works even off the track (though, of course, it's better as a set).

Elmo comes with a few songs, and the music is very loud and audible--a good thing, especially considering his small size.

The set folds up nicely for storage. Since my daughter has a crap ton of toys, making this more portable and foldable is a nice feature.

It's a great toy set to have, albeit at a steep price. My guess is for the licensing and electronics. The track is nice and big and sturdy, and I presume compatible with other sets in the line.

title: A fun addition to the picnic set.
text:
My daughter loves this thing, even though we tried to keep it locked away till her birthday. But she eventually kept finding it, and playing with it from within its box. So we decided to give it to her a week early.

We have the picnic basket that complements this set, and it's nice overall to have both sets to play along. The volume on this tea set is great and loud, and leaves the sound chips and speakers from my infant days in the dust.

I like that the spout is sensitive to its angle, so it knows when it's being poured and when it's "empty." The colors are vibrant, corresponding to the pie flavors, and actually diminish once the supposed tea runs out. There are also modes which help distinguish how many cups it's being poured into.
The songs are cheerful, and my daughter loves opening and shutting the lid to hear them, as she does on the picnic basket.

The pieces are sturdy enough to take a whacking. For the price, this set is pretty awesome, and my daughter and both my wife and I have a blast playing with it, whether it's tea time or just throwing the pieces around.

title: Ordered by accident, but a hit anywho.
text:
We're pretty new to the whole Tag system here in my household, and I actually accidentally ordered this thinking it was age-appropriate for my daughter. While it isn't, seeing as she's shy of two, we are still using it together, and it maintains her interest long enough.

We have supplementary books as well, and are using them around bedtime in conjunction with her story time. The pen intrigues her more than the books themselves.

title: Pricey, but a great LP addition to my daughter's collection!
text:
Seeing as my daughter is about to turn one, we thought this toy would be too much for her. But she received another Little People set for her birthday, and she plays with it non-stop. Thus, we decided to open this one a little early as well, and she's hooked on Little People.

Though she mostly eats the princesses and their ponies, my daughter loves to be able to play with the different LP sets interchangeably. I sometimes show her how she's *supposed* to be using them, having her get a sense of the sounds and how they are activated. The play set itself is pretty neat, and doesn't take up much room in either the living room or the little play nook in her bedroom. And come on: What little girl doesn't like Disney princesses?

A great addition to her toy chest, though I admit much of the pricing can be a little high for LP sets.

title: BROKE!!! Doesn't seem too durable, but my daughter loves it, and that's what matters.
text:
***UPDATE 08/29/13***
My daughter, who is one, went to grab Elmo the other day. Elmo was sitting against the couch on the floor, and my daughter grabbed his foot to bring him to her. The head fell on the floor, obviously, but there was an audible *thunk*, and my wife and I looked at each other. I immediately went to test out the doll, and found it no longer worked. I replaced the batteries, but that did nothing.

It stinks that a simple drop from a resting position would make Elmo completely inoperable. Again, he was already sitting on the floor, so the fall wasn't that great.

Ah, well. At least my daughter can use it as a regular Elmo doll. A $50 Elmo doll with stiff arms and a hard head.
***

First thought I had: This Elmo is HUGE!
My daughter is only a year old, but she's already obsessed with the little red monster. We decided to get this for her, and when we opened the Amazon box we found it to be bigger than even her!

The electronics are great and interactive, as Elmo constantly wants a hug from my daughter. Being that my daughter is not even a year old and doesn't fully understand speech and its many commands, she ignores Elmo's pleas, opting instead to hold him by his arms or legs. She'll hug him--when she wants.

The arms are fine and seem sturdy enough, but I'm afraid they won't last long time. Hopefully they'll last as long as my daughter's infatuation with the creature, but I don't expect this one staying with the family for generations.

It's a great Elmo to have. I think the high price is due mainly to the height of the figure. I've seen electronic toys with more gizmos go for cheaper, so my guess is the height and licensing.

A great Elmo toy. As if the other two my daughter had weren't enough.

title: Fun to build with family.
text:
I'm not much into puzzles, but I've been wanting to try some decent ones for quite some time. Ever since reading Death Note and seeing Near's blank white puzzle, that's what I wanted to try. But I figured, "Let's try something easier first. At least something with pictures." So that's why I ordered this puzzle.

It's got the image of the very familiar Neuschwanstein (or the "Disney castle"), and the brilliant colors make the pieces a wee bit easier to find.
But man, I didn't know the pieces would be so small! I realize it's to conserve table space and make the puzzle more challenging, but it's quite a shock for someone so new to puzzles, like me.

It was a joy to build, though it probably took me longer than it would've others. I've already two more Ravensburger puzzles, and yes, one is blank!

title: Fun for all ages!
text:
This is such a neat little plaything. I have it set in my office at home, and anyone that ventures in picks it up and doesn't put it down until one of two things happen: they succeed, or, more likely, the become frustrated after half an hour.

I've handled it a few times, and have succeeded only ever once. It appears simple upon initial glance, but it is a great thing for amusement for both kids and adults, and even better to have at the office.

I may bring it to my work office to see how much play it gets!

title: A baby TV.
text:
As with many new gizmos today for kids, the Fisher-Price digital soother attempts to take as much "app" technology into itself to make it as modern and technologically advanced as possible. Unfortunately, it doesn't mean it's always going to be great. Still, I noticed that my month-old daughter did find immediate comfort when I tested the soother out last week.

It's fairly easy to install, though I still grow weary that it'll stay on the crib and won't fall on her face (it's relatively heavy). The soother is easy to attach to the base and remove, and there are settings that make it easy to dim the backscreen light and turn down the volume. However, once I realized it's not touchscreen, I sort of grew upset. I know I should've done my research and known it wasn't a touch screen before ordering, but c'est la vie.

There are a few buttons only on the soother, which means there are going to be more steps to navigate through the menus than necessary. FP should've made more buttons to navigate easier, and a couple wheels to quickly and easily adjust the brightness and volume. You have to adjust the both each for every "app," which grows rather annoying after a while. The glamorized TV for infants turned out to soothe my daughter after all, and she stayed fixated (with what limited vision she has now) on the sound and slow movements of the nighttime app. I've yet to install more apps, but the included ones seem fine for now. It really is just a TV with no interaction for my daughter.

For the price, I'd probably go with something with which my kid can interact. I don't like the idea that she's just sitting there propped next to the soother while it plays like a TV. Otherwise, if this is something you're looking for, it seems well built (but heavy), comes with a convenient kickstand, and lets you customize and add the apps.

title: Electronic Yahtzee Flash
text:
From my wife:

I had high hopes for this game and thought it would be a great game to play with the kids that I work with, but after receiving it, I was disappointed. This game is very difficult to keep up with due to its fast pace. It's much harder to catch onto this game than the original version. This game is electronic and may be more enticing for children compared to the regular Yahtzee. It is also fairly portable which makes it convenient to take with you on trips. However, this game is more expensive than the regular game and is not, in my opinion, worth the extra money. Looking at all of the features of regular Yahtzee and comparing them to this digital version, I highly prefer the regular Yahtzee game versus this digital version. If you have never played the regular Yahtzee game, you may have a different take on this one.

title: Great, simple fun.
text:
This is an excellent "spin" of the game Sorry! It fits in well with the younger crowd, and very entertaining for adults.
I'm personally more into strategy and Euro games, but every once in a while I like to lean my head back and have a game of simplicity. Sorry! Spin fits the bill just fine.

The object of the game is just like regular Sorry!, except here the board is circular, and there are cards that can turn the main board of the game, thus making some pieces closer to home than before, and some far behind.
It certainly needs a lot of adult help, as the game pretty much comes as a kit. You have to build the game right down to the card tuck box, but once it's built it only needs minor dismantlement to put back away. The pieces do seem a bit flimsy, so don't go smashing your fist on it if someone sends your piece back to start!

title: Nice luxurious size for a big dog!
text: This seems to measure larger than most other dog pools available, and it does seem sturdy. I originally purchased it at a discount through the warehouse deals. The pool arrived with a cracked drain cap so it wouldn't hold water above that line. I contacted Vistop regarding a replacement cap. Initially they wanted pictures which is hard for me. The crack wouldn't show that well and I'm not great at uploading photo's. Besides, I was asking for just a new cap, not a new pool. However, after some back and forths, Vistop customer service actually sent me a whole new pool which was great service.  I'm going with 4 stars rather than 5 because I do find it hard to drain. Maybe I'm not understanding how it's suppose to be done, but I have trouble keeping the drain hole open so it will drain out. I more or less have to dump out the water by lifting it up some which I find a bit difficult. Overall, my dog really enjoys it and it does seem expansive and sturdy, so I'm pleased with both the product and the customer service.

title: Excellent Montessori product
text: I purchased this product for my two and three year old nieces. I like to use toys and games that offer a Montessori approach as much as possible. This set matches that description wonderfully. Beautifully constructed out of large wooden beads and painted in bright non toxic colors. The beads themselves are nicely split between fruit, vegetables and animals. Readily recognized by my three year old niece. Four beading strings tipped with a small wood stylus to make threading easier. Both girls were able to use this product, however the three year old really hit her stride with this product. She sat content with this product for between 25-45 minutes on the first session. Both girls also asked for it again later. I would use this product with supervision as there is a small chance of choking with some of the smaller beads and the stylus is pointed and could be used inappropriately (poking eyes, ears etc). Otherwise, I highly recommend this product, very reasonably priced, appears durable for toddlers through probably the early grades if you have young kids with you are working with fine notary skills etc, or you are looking for a reusable planet friendly product. Comes with a nice little carry bag as well for travel and came with some bonus stickers.

title: Simplicity
text: I bought this as a gift for my niece. She loves arts and crafts. I loves the fact they use mainly wood instead of plastic. I was expecting a standing easel, the size of this is more appropriate to something you would set on a desk or table top unless the kid sits on the floor. In addition, I both compliment and complain about the box. They clearly designed it to be as planet friendly as possibly with easy access, but when I opened it to verify that everything was intact (it came boxed with other goods from Amazon and I wanted to ensure it wasn't damaged) it was quite difficult to fit everything back in the box.
